description: The Graduate Certificate in Accelerator Science at Stony Brook University aims to provide post-baccalaureate students with a solid and specialized background in the physics and technology of particle accelerators. This is achieved through a set of core courses that focus on accelerator physics and technology, along with a number of specialized elective courses and, notably, a practical training experience in one of the accelerator facilities operated by the Center for Accelerator Science and Education (CASE) at Stony Brook.

The Master of Science in Accountancy (MSA) is a 30-credit, one-year graduate program that prepares students for careers in public accounting, industry, non-profit, and government. Stony Brook's MSA is designed for students with an undergraduate degree in accounting, as well as for those without an accounting background. The program offers a flexible curriculum that enables students to customize their coursework to their specific career goals. Core courses provide students with a strong foundation in the fundamentals of accounting, while electives allow them to specialize in areas such as forensic accounting, taxation, and information systems. In addition to our rigorous coursework, the MSA program provides students with opportunities to gain practical experience through internships and other experiential learning opportunities. We also have a strong network of alumni who are eager to help our students succeed.
Accreditation status: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, a hallmark of excellence earned by less than five percent of business schools worldwide.

description: The 30-credit, one-year Master of Science in Accounting program prepares students for a career in public accounting, and is designed to meet the educational requirements for CPA licensure in New York State. An undergraduate degree in accounting is not required, as we offer prerequisite courses in business and accounting that may be taken at Stony Brook as a non-matriculated student. Students will gain the knowledge of accounting, auditing, taxation, and technology necessary to become a successful accounting professional. They also have the ability to pursue specialized accounting knowledge by taking elective courses in topics such as forensic accounting, finance, operations management, human resources and marketing. The curriculum is enhanced with a strong emphasis on technology and quantitative analysis with courses in Business Analytics, and advanced data analytics in accounting. The required internship helps students gain hands-on professional experience to advance their career. Our experienced faculty include esteemed researchers and practitioners who are experts in their fields, dedicated to preparing students to become leaders in accounting.
Accreditation status: Stony Brook University's College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. AACSB accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education and has been earned by less than five percent of the world's business programs.

description: The MBA in Accounting degree program is designed for students with an undergraduate major in accounting from a U.S. college or university. This full-time program, which can be completed in two semesters, allows graduates to meet the 150-credit hour requirement needed to sit for the CPA exam in New York State and many other states. Students can also qualify for advanced standing in the program, which will reduce their cost and time to degree. Stony Brook’s MBA in Accounting will not only prepare you for the CPA exam, but also to assume a leadership role in an accounting firm or corporation. In addition to a strong accounting foundation, the program features courses in finance, management, operations, and marketing, all taught by our world-class faculty. Graduates of the program are well prepared for careers in public accounting, corporate accounting, not-for-profit accounting, and government.
Accreditation status: Stony Brook University's College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, the premier accrediting agency for business schools in the world.

Concentration name: Accounting Analytics, Accounting and Financial Management
description: The Master of Science in Accounting (MSA) program is designed for students with an undergraduate degree in accounting who wish to focus on a particular area within the field or for students with an undergraduate degree in a discipline other than accounting who are interested in pursuing a career in accounting. This program offers students an opportunity to obtain a graduate degree from a top-ranked research university that is accredited by AACSB International, the premier accrediting agency for business schools. The program also positions students to become a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) in New York State. The MS in Accounting program has two tracks: Accounting Analytics and Accounting and Financial Management. The Accounting Analytics track is a STEM-designated program that provides students with the advanced data analytics skills they need for a successful career in the growing field of accounting analytics. The Accounting and Financial Management track provides students with technical accounting skills and prepares students for a career in public or corporate accounting.
Accreditation status: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, a prestigious body that recognizes the top business schools in the world.

Concentration name: Finance, Marketing, Health Care Management, Operations Management, Innovation, Accounting
description: The Combined Bachelor's/MBA program is an opportunity for ambitious undergraduate students to earn a bachelor's degree in their chosen major and a Master of Business Administration degree with a concentration in Finance, Marketing, Health Care Management, Operations Management, Innovation, or Accounting. Students in the Combined Bachelor's/MBA program will be able to complete all the requirements for both degrees in five years, saving a full year of time and tuition. Students may select from any of our six MBA concentrations, or they may opt for the general MBA and choose from a variety of electives that best suit their academic and career goals. This allows them the flexibility to design their own course of study in fields such as general management, human resources, or business analytics. The Combined Bachelor's/MBA program will prepare students for leadership roles in a variety of careers.
Accreditation status: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International

description: The Accelerated Master of Public Health (MPH) degree at Stony Brook University is designed for highly-qualified, currently-enrolled undergraduate and graduate students, as well as recent graduates, who wish to complete both a bachelor’s degree and a MPH degree, or a clinical doctorate and an MPH degree, in less time than it would take to complete them sequentially. Through our flexible accelerated programs, students gain advanced skills and knowledge to address complex public health issues and become leaders in the field.
Accreditation status: The Program in Public Health at Stony Brook University is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH). Our program was first accredited in 2011 and was reaccredited in 2018 for a seven-year term, extending to July 1, 2025.

description: The Advanced Certificate in Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner (AGACNP) program prepares acute care nurse practitioners to provide advanced nursing care to adult and gerontological patients with complex, acute, and chronic health conditions. This is a 27-credit program that includes 600 clinical hours. Students are prepared to provide a full spectrum of care from disease prevention to critical care in order to stabilize the patient’s condition, prevent complications, restore health and/or provide palliative care. Students who complete the program are eligible to take the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Association of Critical-Care Nurses (AACN) certification exam.
Accreditation status: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, Doctor of Nursing Practice program and advanced certificate programs at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner Certificate

description: The Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner program prepares the graduate with the knowledge and skills to provide advanced nursing care to the adult and gerontology population with complex, acute, and chronic health conditions. Emphasis is on the provision of health care services to patients who are acutely and critically ill in a variety of settings such as intensive care units, emergency departments, specialty labs, and specialty clinics. Clinical experiences with expert preceptors are provided in a variety of settings. Graduates of the Master of Science in Nursing in the Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner program will be eligible to sit for national certification through the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Association of Critical Care Nurses (AACN).
Accreditation status: The master's degree program in nursing... at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, 202-887-6791.
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Acute Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

description: The Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner program is designed to prepare students to provide primary health care to the adult-gerontology population across the wellness-illness continuum. The program emphasizes health promotion, health maintenance, disease prevention and the management of common acute and chronic illnesses. The program provides the foundational knowledge and clinical skills for graduates to be eligible for both New York State NP certification and national certification by the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners (AANP).
Accreditation status: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, Doctor of Nursing Practice program and post-graduate APRN certificate programs at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner Certificate

description: The Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner program is a 45-credit master's degree that prepares students to provide primary care to the entire spectrum of adults, from adolescents to older adults. The curriculum focuses on health promotion, health protection, disease prevention and the management of common acute and chronic illnesses. Graduates of this program are eligible to sit for the Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner certification examination offered by the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC) or the American Academy of Nurse Practitioners (AANP). The program's part-time plan of study allows students to continue working while pursuing their degree.
Accreditation status: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and Doctor of Nursing Practice program at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (http://www.ccneaccreditation.org).
Program name: Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner MSN

description: The General Practice Residency Program at Stony Brook University Hospital is an intense, hospital-based dental training program with a strong emphasis on medical and dental care for medically complex patients. The program provides the resident with advanced training in all aspects of general dentistry, with rotations in anesthesiology, general medicine and emergency medicine. The primary goal of our program is to produce well-rounded practitioners competent in all aspects of dentistry who have a robust understanding of the intricacies of a hospital-based dental practice.
Accreditation status: The program is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation (CODA) of the American Dental Association.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program General Practice Residency

description: The School of Dental Medicine offers a 36-month, CODA-accredited advanced education program leading to a Certificate of Completion in Dental Anesthesiology. It is one of only two hospital-based dental anesthesiology training programs in the United States administered by a Department of Anesthesiology within a medical school. The program provides a solid foundation in clinical anesthesia for dental specialists who will be able to provide advanced anesthesia and pain control services for ambulatory and hospitalized patients. The program provides comprehensive training in all phases of anesthesia care for dental, oral and maxillofacial surgery, and other surgical subspecialties. Residents gain extensive experience in the anesthetic management of patients of all ages, including pediatrics, and those with special needs or who are medically compromised. Upon completion of the program, residents will be eligible for board certification by the American Dental Board of Anesthesiology (ADBA). The Stony Brook University Hospital based program is a Level 1 Trauma Center, providing a broad range of anesthesia experiences to dental residents including rotations at the Ambulatory Surgical Center. Our residents are trained side-by-side with their physician anesthesiology counterparts. During the 36 months, the dental anesthesia residents complete the same rotations as the medical anesthesiology residents with an additional emphasis on ambulatory anesthesia. They learn skills such as outpatient anesthetic techniques, advanced airway management, pediatric anesthesia and anesthesia for patients with special needs or who are medically-compromised. The comprehensive didactic program complements the clinical experience. Graduates of this program will be well-prepared to become competent practitioners, educators, and researchers.
Accreditation status: The Advanced Education Program in Dental Anesthesiology at Stony Brook School of Dental Medicine is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation and has been granted the accreditation status of approval without reporting requirements.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program in Dental Anesthesiology

description: The Advanced Education Program in Endodontics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a 24-month program leading to a Certificate in Endodontics. The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association Commission on Dental Accreditation. The program is designed to educate qualified dentists to become specialists in endodontics. It will provide the postdoctoral student with a strong background in the biological sciences and their application to clinical endodontics. The program emphasizes the scientific basis for the clinical practice of endodontics. This will be achieved through a comprehensive series of scheduled lectures, seminars, and laboratory courses designed to complement the student's clinical experience. The postdoctoral student will be assigned a wide variety of clinical cases, both surgical and non-surgical. The student is encouraged to participate in original research, which should be of publishable quality and is a requirement for graduation. The School of Dental Medicine provides all endodontic instrumentation, including several brands of rotary instrumentation, ultrasonics, and thermoplastic obturation systems. State of the art operating microscopes are provided for each resident. All radiography is digital using phosphor plates and direct sensors. CBCT imaging is readily available.
Accreditation status: The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association Commission on Dental Accreditation.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program in Endodontics

description: The School of Dental Medicine offers an advanced education certificate program in oral and maxillofacial radiology, which is designed to provide training in the interpretation of conventional and advanced images, such as computed tomography (CT), cone beam computed tomography (CBCT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The goal of the residency program is to prepare residents to practice as specialists in oral and maxillofacial radiology. The educational philosophy is to consider the residents as colleagues and provide them with a broad background in the field of oral and maxillofacial radiology to assure a high level of clinical competency and to provide them with the tools and techniques of research in the field. The program provides the educational experience to allow the resident to meet the eligibility requirements for examination for certification by the American Board of Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology. The program is designed for two years of study and clinical experience, culminating in a certificate in oral and maxillofacial radiology. During this time, residents will gain experience and advanced knowledge in radiation physics, radiation biology, radiation safety, radiographic techniques, interpretation of conventional and advanced imaging modalities, and clinical correlation of disease. At the end of the program, the resident is expected to be proficient in the interpretation of conventional and advanced imaging modalities utilized in the diagnosis and management of diseases affecting the oral and maxillofacial region in the hospital and private practice settings.
Accreditation status: The advanced education program in Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation and has been granted the accreditation status of initial accreditation.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program in Oral and Maxillofacial Radiology

description: The postgraduate program in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a thirty-six month course of study, which provides a Certificate of Proficiency in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics and fulfills the educational requirements for eligibility for the American Board of Orthodontics Examination. In addition, an optional Master of Science degree in Oral Biology and Pathology is offered. The program, which accepts four residents each year, is designed to provide a comprehensive and balanced didactic and clinical orthodontic education. Our main objective is to develop outstanding, clinically proficient practitioners who will be able to successfully manage the full range of orthodontic problems. The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association’s Commission on Dental Accreditation. Upon completion, graduates are well prepared for the American Board of Orthodontics clinical examination.
Accreditation status: The program is fully accredited by the American Dental Association’s Commission on Dental Accreditation.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program in Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics

description: The Advanced Education Program in Pediatric Dentistry is a 24-month university and hospital-based program. The program is designed to offer a balanced clinical and didactic curriculum in advanced infant, child and adolescent dentistry. The program provides the resident with the necessary training to become a competent pediatric dental specialist. Emphasis is placed on hospital dentistry, special needs patient care, pediatric medicine, growth and development, and interceptive orthodontics. Upon successful completion of all requirements, the resident receives a Certificate in Pediatric Dentistry. Graduates are educationally qualified for the American Board of Pediatric Dentistry examination. Residents may concurrently enroll in a Master of Science in Oral Biology and Pathology program offered by the Graduate School of Stony Brook University. The goal of this optional track is to provide an in-depth experience in the research process.
Accreditation status: The Advanced Education Program in Pediatric Dentistry is accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation and has been granted the accreditation status of “approval without reporting requirements”.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program in Pediatric Dentistry

description:
The Advanced Education Program in Periodontics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a thirty-six (36) month program designed to provide an outstanding educational experience and to satisfy the formal training requirements of the American Board of Periodontology. The program, which is based at the School of Dental Medicine, enrolls three residents each year. At the completion of the program, the resident is awarded a Certificate in Periodontics. The program is fully accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation of the American Dental Association.

The primary objective of the Advanced Education Program in Periodontics is to graduate competent periodontists. This competency is founded in a strong understanding of the biological basis of clinical periodontics, an appreciation of the importance of an evidence-based approach to patient care, and sound clinical judgment and skill. The curriculum provides for a broad-based education in periodontology including didactic and clinical components in the areas of diagnosis and treatment planning for patients with a wide variety of periodontal diseases, surgical and non-surgical periodontal therapy, oral medicine, pain and anxiety control, oral implantology, and principles of practice management. Additionally, a Master's degree (M.S. in Oral Biology and Pathology) is available as an option. The Master's program must be completed within the 36-month periodontics residency.
Accreditation status: The program is fully accredited by the Commission on Dental Accreditation of the American Dental Association.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program in Periodontics

description: The Advanced Education Program in Prosthodontics at Stony Brook University School of Dental Medicine is a three-year program which combines didactic and clinical instruction leading to a Certificate in Prosthodontics. The program offers residents extensive experience in all aspects of prosthodontics, including complete dentures, removable partial dentures, fixed prosthodontics, esthetics, and implant dentistry. Strong emphasis is placed on diagnosis, treatment planning and execution of all facets of prosthodontic care. Residents are also expected to complete a research project and a manuscript suitable for publication. Residents may also elect to complete the requirements for a Master of Science in Oral Biology and Pathology at the same time.
Accreditation status: The Advanced Education Program in Prosthodontics is fully accredited by the American Dental Association's Commission on Dental Accreditation.
Program name: Advanced Dental Education Program in Prosthodontics

description: The AGC in Data and Computational Science is intended for students who have completed an undergraduate degree and wish to acquire specialized knowledge in data and computational science. The certificate will prepare students for careers in data science and analytics as well as for further graduate study. Students will choose one of two tracks: either an emphasis in computational and statistical methods for big data, or an emphasis in a domain-specific area of their choosing. Students will be required to meet with the graduate program director to formulate their plan of study upon entering the certificate program. For more information, contact the graduate program director for the DCS-AGC.
Program name: Advanced Graduate Certificate in data and computational science

description: The Master of Arts in Advertising is a new, innovative program in the School of Communication and Journalism that will help you gain the knowledge and skills necessary to become a leader in the advertising industry. In this program, you will learn to manage advertising and marketing campaigns, develop and implement communication strategies and tactics, and create compelling content for a variety of audiences and platforms. The program is designed to be completed in one calendar year (fall, spring, summer), and classes are held in the evenings to accommodate working professionals. You will learn from seasoned advertising and marketing professionals and gain hands-on experience through client-based projects, case studies, and a capstone portfolio project. The MA in Advertising is ideal for students who are just starting their careers, as well as those who are already in the field and want to move into leadership roles. You will graduate from this program with a strong portfolio of work that will help you land a job in the fast-paced and exciting world of advertising.

The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Africana Studies allows Stony Brook graduate students to develop expertise in the field of Africana Studies and to receive formal recognition for their training and research on campus. Students complete five courses (15 credits) on topics related to Africana Studies, which are taught by faculty affiliates from across the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Social Welfare, the School of Journalism, and the School of Medicine. Our program includes a diverse intellectual community, including regular talks, workshops, and roundtables with leading scholars in the field of Africana Studies. The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Africana Studies also provides graduate students with crucial professionalization for today's competitive job market, including within and beyond the academy.

The Department of Africana Studies at Stony Brook University offers a Master of Arts degree that prepares students for interdisciplinary scholarship in the field of Africana Studies and for professional careers that require advanced knowledge of the histories, cultures, and political economies of people of African descent in the United States, the Caribbean, Latin America, Africa, and the wider African Diaspora. The curriculum is interdisciplinary, drawing on a wide range of theoretical and methodological approaches from the humanities and social sciences. The program emphasizes a diasporic, comparative, and transnational approach to the study of the African world. Students will engage with a variety of research methods and theoretical perspectives, including postcolonial theory, critical race theory, feminism and womanism, cultural studies, and political economy. The M.A. program in Africana Studies also equips students with the research and writing skills necessary to succeed in a variety of Ph.D. programs and professional fields.

This 18-credit advanced certificate is intended to meet the needs of those individuals, in a variety of fields, who work with the aged. The program is specifically designed to provide specialized knowledge about the aging process which will supplement the generalist skills of administrators, planners, and clinicians who are, or will be, working with the elderly. The purpose of the advanced certificate program is to provide students with the ability to: analyze the economic, political, and social issues associated with aging populations; understand the physiological and psychological aspects of aging; evaluate the ethical and legal issues in healthcare; evaluate marketing and strategic planning for serving aging populations; understand the structure, financing, and management of the long-term continuum of care. The program is offered in an online format.
Program name: Aging Populations and Healthcare Administration, Advanced Certificate

description: The graduate program in Anatomical Sciences at Stony Brook University is a two-year program designed to train students for careers teaching the anatomical disciplines in medical and allied health science schools or for careers in which a thorough knowledge of anatomy is a prime requisite. The program provides the students with a comprehensive background in the major areas of the anatomical sciences, with special emphasis on the gross anatomy, microscopic anatomy, neuroanatomy and development of the human body. As an integral component of the program, students gain experience in the teaching of the anatomical sciences by participating as teaching assistants in the anatomy courses for medical, dental, and allied health science students. This aspect of the program provides the students with supervised practical experience and thus the opportunity to teach in a professional school environment.

Concentration name: Vertebrate Paleontology and Evolution, Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics, Human Evolutionary Biology, Developmental and Cellular Biology
description: The Anatomical Sciences graduate program is designed for students interested in the evolutionary basis of vertebrate, especially mammalian and primate, structure. Our faculty are clustered in four major research areas in which students can specialize: Vertebrate Paleontology and Evolution, Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics, Human Evolutionary Biology, and Developmental and Cellular Biology. The program fosters an understanding of the relationship between organismal structure and function from the molecular to the gross anatomical levels. Students learn the importance of studying anatomy within an evolutionary and functional context. Our program aims to give students a broad exposure to the anatomical sciences while fostering the specialization necessary for an independent research career.

The doctoral program in Anthropological Sciences (DPA) is an interdepartmental graduate program administered by the Department of Anthropology. The focus of the program is on the application of the natural sciences to the solution of anthropological problems, both past and present. Students admitted to the DPA may specialize in either (1) evolutionary anthropology, which focuses on the evolutionary history and biocultural adaptations of humans and other primates, or (2) archaeology, which addresses anthropological problems through the study of the material remains of past human behavior. The DPA program emphasizes research design and the development of analytical skills that allow students to carry out original, problem-oriented research.

The graduate program in anthropology provides training in the three major subdisciplines of the field: archaeology, biological anthropology, and sociocultural anthropology. The faculty consists of 19 full-time members. These faculty, often jointly with faculty in other departments such as Anatomical Sciences, Art, Ecology and Evolution, Geosciences, and History, offer a wide variety of specialized training and research opportunities. In addition to the regular course work, students benefit from a large number of research projects directed by the faculty in many parts of the world, including North, Central and South America; Africa; and Asia. A number of research laboratories and other facilities are available within the department and elsewhere on campus, including the new Turkana Basin Institute. The department also has close ties with several area museums. The Department of Anthropology does not offer a terminal M.A. degree. The M.A. is awarded as a qualifying degree en route to the Ph.D.

Our department has established a new Master of Arts in Anthropology degree with a concentration in Applied Biological Anthropology. This program builds on our strengths in biological anthropology and will emphasize the practical and analytical skills necessary for careers in government, non-profits, and the private sector, as well as for further study in academic PhD programs. Coursework and training will be offered in a variety of topical areas within applied biological anthropology, and include: Functional Anatomy and Biomechanics; Human Osteology; Forensic Anthropology; Medical Anthropology; Human-Environment Interactions; Anthropological Genetics; and Geometric Morphometrics. The Masters of Arts in Anthropology with a Concentration in Applied Biological Anthropology is a two-year, 30-credit degree designed for students with a bachelor’s degree (in any field) who are interested in pursuing advanced training in biological anthropology, but who do not intend to pursue a PhD, or wish to strengthen their record before applying for a PhD. This program offers advanced coursework and training in a variety of topical areas within biological anthropology, and places special emphasis on the practical and analytical skills necessary for careers in government, non-profits, and the private sector, as well as for further study in academic PhD programs. Stony Brook University is known for its strength in biological anthropology, and this program provides a unique opportunity for students to acquire a Master’s degree from a world-renowned department, regardless of their undergraduate background. Students may enroll on either a full-time or a part-time basis. Full-time students may complete the degree in as few as three semesters.
Program name: Concentration in Applied Biological Anthropology (Anthropology MA)

description: The goal of the ACG certificate program is to provide geoscientists a world class training in carbonate geology, with an emphasis on carbonate sedimentology and stratigraphy, diagenesis, petrophysics and reservoir characterization. It can be taken as a stand-alone certificate to bolster your skill set, or in conjunction with our M.S. or Ph.D. programs in geosciences. The certificate program requires 18 credits of coursework, including a series of core courses and a range of optional advanced courses. The certificate program has been designed to meet the needs of those seeking advanced training in carbonate sedimentology/stratigraphy for careers in academia, government, and industry.

The Master of Science (M.S.) degree program in Applied Health Informatics (AHI) is offered through the Department of Biomedical Informatics (BMI) in the Stony Brook University School of Medicine. Our program is uniquely situated within an academic medical center and students will be exposed to both the research driven academic world as well as the applied operational world of the Stony Brook Medicine. The goal of the program is to train the next generation of informaticians who will be have the skills, knowledge and abilities to work as professional informaticians or to go on to PhD programs in informatics. The curriculum provides a strong technical and computer science foundation, a comprehensive understanding of the health and clinical environment, and familiarity with social and organizational issues in healthcare. These three pillars: computer science, the clinical environment, and social science/organizational issues are the essential components for well-trained informaticians. The AHI program trains future informaticians through our innovative curriculum, and our strong partnerships with the Stony Brook Medicine, Long Island Health Information Exchange, area hospitals, industry and public health agencies in the greater NY area. Students gain real-world experience through our practicum/capstone course which provides an opportunity to apply informatics principles to an active project in a health care setting. Our students will develop specialized expertise in health informatics and be prepared for positions in the health care industry or for advanced study in the field.

The EdD in Applied Learning Sciences (ALS) is a 48-credit, fully online program designed to advance the expertise of learning professionals in a variety of industries, including K-12 and higher education, corporate, non-profit, government, and military settings. The program will equip students with advanced knowledge and skills in learning sciences to design, implement, and evaluate technology-mediated learning environments. Core coursework explores learning theory and design, human cognition, program evaluation, research methods and data analytics, as well as emerging educational technologies. This applied doctoral program is practice-based and leads to a culminating doctoral project. In keeping with the practitioner-scholar focus, students will learn to identify real-world problems of practice and apply research-based approaches and solutions that will have a direct impact on learning and teaching.

The Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics offers a program of graduate study leading to the Master of Science degree. This program is designed for students who seek to obtain a higher level of knowledge in their chosen field of specialization. Four tracks are offered for the M.S. degree. Two of them are in operations research and statistics, which have long been the two principal areas of applied mathematics. The other two are in quantitative finance, an area of ever increasing importance and interest, and in computational applied mathematics, which emphasizes methods relevant to solving major scientific and engineering problems. A brief description of these areas of specialization is below. Each track gives students a great deal of flexibility in designing a course of study that will meet their own particular educational objectives.

The Ph.D. program in Applied Mathematics and Statistics is designed to train students to become leading researchers and educators in the various fields of applied mathematics and statistics. It is an individualized program of study for highly qualified students. Its principal components are a broad training in applied mathematics and an in-depth specialization in one of the major research areas of the department: computational applied mathematics, computational biology, operations research, or statistics.

The Applied Physiology, M.S.Ed. is a 30-credit master's degree program that develops professionals who are both excellent healthcare providers and exemplary educators in the clinical setting. The graduate program provides a strong foundation in physiology and hands-on, research and educational experiences that prepare students to integrate evidence-based practice into their future careers. Students within the program can choose a general focus or a more specialized area of study, such as human performance, exercise physiology, pathophysiology, or health and wellness. This program is ideal for students who aspire to careers in professional healthcare fields like medicine, dentistry, physical therapy, occupational therapy, and physician assistant, as well as students with interests in athletic training, sports medicine, exercise physiology, or teaching in a healthcare setting.

The Master of Professional Studies (MPS) in Applied Remote Sensing is an interdisciplinary graduate program that blends foundational knowledge with hands-on technical training to meet the growing need for expertise in the processing, analysis, and application of remotely sensed data for a wide range of academic, industrial, and government career tracks. Remote sensing refers to the collection and interpretation of information about an object or area from a distance, typically by sensors on aircraft and satellites. Students will explore diverse topics in remote sensing theory and applications, including: the physical principles of remote sensing, digital image processing, and analysis, unpiloted aerial systems (UAS; i.e. drones), satellite and airborne remote sensing, and programming for geospatial applications. The curriculum integrates knowledge and skills across academic disciplines, including Geosciences, Ecology and Evolution, and Marine Sciences, to equip students with the ability to answer complex questions related to environmental systems and resources. This program does not currently accept applications.

Concentration name: Finfish, Shellfish, and Algal Aquaculture; Restoration Aquaculture
description: The Master of Professional Studies (MPS) in Aquaculture is an accelerated, 30-credit, non-thesis degree program designed for students who desire practical training in the diverse fields of aquaculture. The MPS degree provides students with the skills and experience necessary for a successful career as an aquaculture professional. The program offers two tracks: 1) Finfish, Shellfish, and Algal Aquaculture, and 2) Restoration Aquaculture. Students will develop expertise in one track and familiarity with the other. This program is offered at the Stony Brook Southampton campus, home to the newly renovated Marine Sciences Center. Students will have access to a state-of-the-art ~2,000 ft2 shellfish and algal culture facility as well as a ~4,000 ft2 finfish culture facility.

Concentration name: structural systems, building envelope and MEP systems
description: The Master of Science in Architectural Engineering (MSAE) is a two-semester program (fall and spring admission) designed to provide students with an engineering-focused graduate degree with an emphasis on building design and performance. The program builds on the undergraduate architectural engineering curriculum at Stony Brook by requiring more in-depth study of the major architectural engineering subject areas: structural systems, building envelope, and mechanical/electrical/plumbing systems. The curriculum provides a balance between theory and practice and addresses modern building design challenges and sustainability. The focus of the program is on building engineering system design, integration, and performance. In addition to coursework in each of the three subject areas, students choose a concentration in structural systems or in building envelope and MEP systems. All students must also complete a comprehensive design project.

The major in Environmental Design, Policy, and Planning (EDP) is an interdisciplinary major in the social sciences that deals with the human dimensions of environmental problems. It combines coursework in environmental studies, economics, political science, sociology and other fields to prepare students for careers in environmental planning, policy, law, and research, or in “green” business and non-profit organizations. EDP majors acquire skills in critical thinking, policy analysis, spatial analysis (GIS), and written and oral communication. The curriculum emphasizes an understanding of social, political, economic, and institutional factors that lead to environmental problems and that must be addressed in order to create more sustainable and resilient societies. Each student is required to complete a 15-credit specialization in a topic of their choice, which may include environmental policy, environmental design, coastal environmental planning, sustainability studies, or GIS.

The Graduate Certificate in Classical Architecture offers students an in-depth exposure to the history, theory, and practice of classical architecture. It allows them to understand how classical principles can be applied to contemporary design. The 18-credit curriculum combines studio courses and seminars that complement professional degree offerings in architecture, urban planning, landscape design, and interior design. The program also provides continuing education opportunities for a wide range of practitioners and others with an interest in the field. Applicants for the graduate certificate must hold a baccalaureate degree. Courses for the certificate program can be taken independently of the degree programs.

The M.A. in Art History and Criticism at Stony Brook is for students who wish to pursue a doctorate in the field, as well as for those who intend to work in museums or other art-related professions. The MA is a two-year, 30-credit program in which students are immersed in the methods and practices of the field. All students are required to take AHI 591, Methods in Art History and Criticism, in their first semester. Over the course of their study, M.A. students are also required to take at least two seminars in each of the three historical areas offered by the department: Pre-Modern (before 1750), Modern (1750–1945), and Contemporary (1945–the present). The program of study is designed with a faculty adviser in consultation with the Graduate Program Director. The program culminates with a qualifying paper, a substantial research paper of publishable quality based on a revised seminar paper, which is completed under the supervision of a faculty adviser in the final semester of study.

The Ph.D. program in Art History and Criticism offers a critical and historical education in the visual arts. The doctoral curriculum at Stony Brook is designed to foster intensive study in a chosen field combined with a broad education in the discipline. The program prepares students for teaching at the college and university level, for curatorial careers in museums, and for a variety of other professions in the arts. Students are expected to devote their full attention to the doctoral program. Fellowships and teaching assistantships provide stipends and tuition scholarships that enable students to focus on their studies.
The Department of Art's faculty in art history and criticism focuses on modern and contemporary art, architecture and visual culture in a global context. The program has particular strengths in American, European, and East Asian art and architecture, and in cross-cultural exchange. Our approach is interdisciplinary. The curriculum combines focused seminars with broad historical and methodological training. The program culminates in a doctoral dissertation that demonstrates the student’s command of a specific area of art history and their ability to make an original contribution to scholarship in the field. Students often pursue interdisciplinary research in collaboration with faculty in other departments, such as history, philosophy, cultural studies, and women's and gender studies.

Concentration name: Studio Art, IMAP (Integrated Media Art and Practice)
description: The graduate program in Art at Stony Brook University offers a course of study leading to the Master of Fine Arts (MFA) degree. The program is dedicated to the notion of the artist as an intellectual and visual explorer. Our curriculum is built around a central core of individual studio work and critical seminars. Within this flexible structure, students are encouraged to develop their own individualized course of study, working with their advisors to combine the available resources of the Department and the University in a way that best suits their particular interests and goals. The MFA is offered in two tracks: Studio Art and the IMAP (Integrated Media Art and Practice) program. While students generally concentrate in a chosen field or medium, such as painting, drawing, sculpture, printmaking, photography, video, electronic media, installation, and performance art, a major emphasis of the program is on the crossing of these boundaries, and on the cross-pollination of ideas and methods. MFA students in the Department of Art also have the opportunity to participate in interdisciplinary study in other departments of the University. This is a 60 credit hour program that emphasizes extensive studio experience in the practice of art. The program also provides opportunities for study in the theory, criticism, and history of art. All graduate students are provided with individual studios. Studio visits are conducted regularly by the full-time faculty and by visiting artists and critics. The Visiting Artist Program brings to campus a diverse and distinguished group of artists, critics, and art historians each semester for lectures, studio visits, and seminars. Art students may choose to supplement their studies with a range of art history, theory, and criticism courses within the Department of Art. In addition to our faculty, graduate students have access to the resources of a major research university, including extensive libraries and computer-imaging facilities. Students also benefit from Stony Brook’s proximity to New York City and its rich cultural resources. The program also offers many opportunities for students to exhibit their work, and there is a final MFA Thesis Exhibition in the final semester. The Lawrence Alloway Memorial Lecture series, supported by an endowment, is an annual event that brings a distinguished art critic to our campus to lecture and meet with graduate students. Other symposia and conferences in the arts are regularly held on campus, providing a stimulating intellectual environment and opportunities to meet and connect with graduate students in other departments, as well as other artists, designers, critics, and scholars.

Concentration name: voice, winds and brass, strings, percussion, or piano
description: This online certificate is designed for students seeking entry to a music program at the collegiate level, as well as high school and private music teachers looking to hone their craft. Students will build a strong foundation in music theory, aural skills, and keyboarding, developing professional skills through applied instruction. Students choose one area of specialization: voice, winds and brass, strings, percussion, or piano.

The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Arts Leadership (ALS) is a 15-credit graduate certificate offered exclusively online through the School of Professional Development. The curriculum is designed for arts professionals with a passion for their field, an entrepreneurial spirit, and a desire to lead a thriving arts organization. Students will learn strategic planning and decision-making, fundraising, financial management, ownership and licensing, and board development and governance. With an emphasis on practical skills, the curriculum equips working professionals to advance to executive-level positions at a wide range of organizations, including museums, galleries, theaters, symphonies, and dance and opera companies.

The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Arts Management program is designed for individuals currently employed in arts organizations or for those who wish to pursue a career in the field. The curriculum focuses on building and enhancing the professional skills necessary to meet the challenges of the arts industry in the 21st century by providing the professional training and education required to foster artistic and organizational success. The five-course curriculum provides a solid foundation of business practices relevant to the unique needs of arts organizations. Students can select courses that specifically target their areas of interest, including marketing, financial management, law, fundraising and development.

The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Arts Presenting Fundamentals is a fully online, 12-credit program that prepares students for careers as arts presenters. Students will gain the skills, knowledge, and network to become leaders in the field of arts presenting by focusing on audience development, community engagement, arts advocacy, programming, financial management and fundraising for nonprofit arts organizations. The program curriculum culminates with an internship, in which students can choose from a wide range of top-tier professional arts organizations throughout the New York metropolitan area. All courses will be conducted by Stony Brook University faculty members and industry leaders in the field of arts presenting. The program can be completed in as little as two semesters.

The master’s degree program in Athletic Training is designed for students who wish to pursue certification as an athletic trainer. The program is specifically designed to provide students with the opportunity to develop the knowledge and skills necessary for the athletic training profession in a variety of clinical settings. Athletic training is practiced by athletic trainers, who are health care professionals. They collaborate with physicians to optimize patient and client activity and participation in athletics, work and life. The practice of athletic training encompasses the prevention, examination and diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation of emergent, acute, subacute, and chronic neuromusculoskeletal conditions and certain medical conditions in order to minimize subsequent impairments, functional limitations, disability, and societal limitations. The master’s degree in Athletic Training will conform to the educational standards set forth by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE). It is a professional program that will require two years of intensive study (including summers) and will offer a curriculum with both a didactic and a clinical component. The didactic portion of the curriculum will offer students a thorough understanding of the theoretical basis of the profession, while the clinical component will provide hands-on experience in a variety of different clinical settings under the supervision of qualified allied health care professionals (e.g., certified athletic trainers, physicians). Students who complete this course of study will be eligible to sit for the Board of Certification (BOC) national examination to become a certified athletic trainer (ATC).
Accreditation status: The master’s degree in Athletic Training is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE).

description: The Master of Science in Athletic Training (MSAT) program is an entry-level professional program for students who have completed a bachelor’s degree and wish to become an athletic trainer. The MSAT program prepares students for a career in athletic training and provides them with the knowledge, skills and abilities to become a successful clinician. The program will emphasize evidence-based practice and encourage life-long learning. The MSAT program requires completion of 63 credits of graduate coursework, including 15 credits of clinical education experiences. Students are afforded multiple opportunities to apply knowledge and skills in a variety of athletic training practice settings under the supervision of qualified clinical preceptors. In addition, students will have the opportunity to engage in a scholarly project in the final semester of the program.
Accreditation status: The Master of Science in Athletic Training program is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Athletic Training Education (CAATE).

description: The graduate program in atmospheric sciences, offered through the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS), is designed to prepare students for careers in research, teaching, and applied meteorology. Two degree programs are available: the MS program, which prepares students for work in operational and applied meteorology or for pursuit of further graduate study, and the PhD program, which prepares students for careers in research and teaching. Coursework and research in the atmospheric sciences program focus on fundamental processes in the atmosphere and at the air-sea interface. Students may elect to work on a broad range of topics, including atmospheric chemistry, boundary-layer and cable meteorology, cloud and precipitation physics, climate and climate change, mesoscale and synoptic meteorology, atmospheric radiation, remote sensing, and tropical meteorology.

The School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) offers the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in marine, atmospheric and terrestrial sciences, and the M.A. degree in marine conservation and policy. Research opportunities are available in biological, chemical, geological and physical oceanography; in atmospheric chemistry, dynamics, and radiation; and in climate studies and terrestrial sciences. The atmospheric sciences program of study leads to the Ph.D. in Marine and Atmospheric Science. Study may be pursued in the following areas: tropical meteorology, including hurricane dynamics, climate dynamics, and the role of the tropics in the global climate system; atmospheric chemistry, especially the study of trace gases and aerosols in the troposphere; the planetary boundary layer and its interaction with the ocean; cloud physics, including the development of precipitation and the interaction of clouds with climate; mesoscale and synoptic-scale meteorology, particularly coastal meteorology; and radiative transfer and remote sensing, including the use of satellite and radar data to study the atmosphere.

The master’s degree program in Biochemistry and Cell Biology provides an advanced education to students seeking careers in medicine and related health fields, biomedical research in academic, government, or industrial settings, as well as teaching. The course-based program focuses on the mechanisms of human disease at the biochemical and cellular levels, and can be completed in one year of full-time study. Students will develop problem solving, critical thinking, and communications skills through coursework and the critical review of scientific literature. Upon completion of the program, students will be able to apply their knowledge to the analysis of biomedical problems.

The Master’s of Science in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (BMB) program is designed for students who wish to pursue a research career in biochemistry and molecular biology. Students graduating with the M.S. degree in BMB will be prepared for a wide variety of job opportunities in academia and industry, including academic research laboratories, pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies, and government. It will also prepare students who are seeking to strengthen their academic credentials for Ph.D. and M.D. programs.

The Biochemistry and Molecular Biology PhD Program trains independent researchers for academic or industrial careers. The first year of the program is spent in intensive course work and in laboratory rotations, designed to provide a broad foundation in modern biochemistry and molecular biology and to expose the student to various research opportunities in the department prior to the choice of a thesis advisor. Advanced courses and seminars in the following years of study are also required. The BMB Program involves a rigorous research component that culminates in the writing and defense of a PhD dissertation. Graduates of our Program are well-prepared for their next career steps, and many have achieved distinguished careers in academic research or in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. See alumni page for examples.

The Graduate Program in Biochemistry and Structural Biology (BSB) offers interdisciplinary training leading to the Ph.D. degree. Research in the BSB Program focuses on the molecular mechanisms of biological processes, with a particular emphasis on the relationship between molecular structure and function. Students in the program gain expertise in a variety of cutting-edge research areas including structural biology (X-ray crystallography, NMR, cryo-EM), drug design, enzymology, chemical biology, molecular biology, and cell biology. Graduates of our program are well prepared for careers in academia, industry (biotechnology and pharmaceutical), education, science policy, and science writing. ... and many others. Faculty in the BSB Program come from several different departments, including Biochemistry and Cell Biology, Chemistry, Pharmacological Sciences, and the School of Medicine, as well as from the nearby Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory. The BSB Program is directed by Dr. Robert Rizzo.

The BSB Graduate Program is part of a larger, interdisciplinary group of graduate programs in the molecular biosciences, collectively organized as the Molecular and Cellular Biology (MCB) Graduate Program. In addition to BSB, the programs include:

Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology (MCP)
Molecular Genetics and Microbiology (MGM)
Neuroscience (NEU)
Genetics (GEN)

Please see www.stonybrook.edu/mcb for a more detailed description of the umbrella program and the individual tracks.

The Bilingual Education Extension is an 18-credit, graduate-level program that leads to New York State certification for teaching in bilingual classrooms. This program may be taken as a stand-alone certificate of advanced study or as a specialization within the MA in TESOL program. It is designed for students who already possess a base certificate in a content area (e.g., English, social studies, science) or in TESOL, and who have achieved the required level of proficiency in both English and a second language. This program is registered with and meets the academic requirements of the New York State Education Department (NYSED).
Accreditation status: This program is registered with and meets the academic requirements of the New York State Education Department (NYSED).

description: The graduate programs in Biological Sciences (BIO) include Biochemistry and Structural Biology; Cell Biology; Ecology and Evolution; Genetics; Molecular and Cellular Biology; Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology; and Neuroscience. These programs emphasize an interdisciplinary approach to graduate training and research. Faculty are drawn from many departments in the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Medicine, and the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences. In addition, scientists at the nearby Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory hold adjunct faculty appointments in the graduate programs and serve as research mentors for graduate students. The graduate programs are designed to prepare students for careers in research and teaching in a wide variety of academic, government, and industrial settings.

The Biology teacher education program is designed to prepare students for careers as secondary school biology teachers. The program is composed of 45-credits of graduate coursework in biology, education and teaching pedagogy, which can lead to a Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) degree. Students may also complete the program as a non-degree student, thereby fulfilling the course requirements for the initial New York State teaching certificate. Students will develop skills to critically analyze curriculum, create and adapt materials, and accommodate the needs of a diverse student population. The program has been nationally recognized by the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA). Students who successfully complete the program and the New York State Teacher Certification Examinations are recommended by Stony Brook for an Initial Teaching Certificate, which allows them to teach biology in grades 7 through 12 in New York State public schools. Note: Students seeking certification in states other than New York are responsible for researching the certification requirements for that state. Students should speak to an advisor about how the Stony Brook program might align with another state's requirements. This program has been approved by the New York State Education Department to be offered in a distance education format (some required courses may be offered only in an online format). Please be aware that if you are a student in an online program who is seeking professional licensure in a state other than New York, you should review the specific requirements for that state on our State Authorization page. Students seeking teaching certification in a state other than New York are advised to review the specific requirements for that state. Students are responsible for verifying that the Stony Brook program meets the educational requirements for the specific license they are seeking in the state in which they seek certification.
Accreditation status: The Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) programs at Stony Brook University are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP), 1140 19th St NW, Suite 400, Washington, DC 20036 (202) 223-0077.

Concentration name: Cellular and Molecular Biology, Ecology and Evolution, Neuroscience, Genetics, Genomics, and Bioinformatics
description:
The Master’s of Science degree program is research-oriented and requires the completion and oral defense of a research thesis. Students in the program work with a faculty advisor within one of the following research specializations:

- Cellular and Molecular Biology
- Ecology and Evolution
- Neuroscience
- Genetics, Genomics, and Bioinformatics

Students in the Cellular and Molecular Biology, Neuroscience and Genetics, Genomics, and Bioinformatics specializations select a faculty advisor from the Department of Neurobiology and Behavior or the Department of Biochemistry and Cell Biology. Students in the Ecology and Evolution specialization select a faculty advisor from the Department of Ecology and Evolution.

The Graduate Program in Ecology and Evolution at Stony Brook University is one of the leading programs in the nation. This is reflected in the high quality of our graduate students and faculty, who regularly publish in the very best scientific journals (e.g., Science, Nature, PNAS, Evolution, Ecology) and in the success of our graduates in obtaining positions in academia, government, and the private sector. Major research areas include evolutionary biology, systematics, population and community ecology, population genetics and genomics, behavioral ecology, conservation biology, disease ecology, and marine and freshwater ecology. Our program provides rigorous training through a combination of coursework, seminars, and the student's own dissertation research. The formal coursework for the Ph.D. is usually completed in two years. In addition to a series of core courses and seminars, each student's course of study is individually designed, with the approval of their dissertation committee, to meet their specific research and career goals. Students and their research are supported by a combination of teaching assistantships, research assistantships, and a variety of fellowships from Stony Brook and from state and federal agencies.

The M.S. in Biomedical Engineering program will prepare students for careers in the biomedical engineering industry or for Ph.D. studies. Students will learn how to apply engineering and biological sciences principles in the development of new medical devices and therapies.

The M.S. degree offers two options: thesis and non-thesis project. The thesis option is research oriented, which is to encourage students who would like to pursue a research career in academia or industry or continue their Ph.D. studies. The non-thesis option is course-oriented, which aims at students who desire to pursue a career in biomedical industry.

Stony Brook's Department of Biomedical Engineering fosters a collaborative research environment that allows for a multidisciplinary approach to problem-solving. We emphasize translational research, moving discoveries from the lab to the patient's bedside. To achieve this, students work alongside clinicians from Stony Brook Medicine, Long Island's premier academic medical center.

Concentration name: ['Biomechanics & Mechanobiology', 'Biomaterials & Regenerative Medicine', 'Bioimaging & Bioinstrumentation', 'Computational Bioengineering & Biomedical Informatics', 'Bioelectricity & Bioelectronics']
description:
The Master of Science in Biomedical Engineering (MSBE) program is designed for students with a bachelor's degree in engineering or the physical/applied sciences. The program provides advanced training appropriate for students who wish to pursue a career in the biomedical engineering industry or continue to a doctoral degree program.

The MSBE program is designed to be completed in one-and-a-half to two years of full-time study. Part-time study is also an option.

Students in the program have the opportunity to participate in groundbreaking research with our world-renowned faculty and have access to our state-of-the-art facilities. The program provides the students flexibility in choosing their area of specialization. Students select one of the following specializations to meet their individual interests and career goals:

The Biomedical Engineering (BME) graduate program offers a Master of Science (MS) degree in BME with an emphasis in Medical Physics. This MS program is designed to prepare students for a career in medical physics, a field which combines the knowledge of physics and engineering with medicine. The program is specifically intended for students with an undergraduate degree in engineering, physics, or another physical science. The MS-BME program with an emphasis in Medical Physics offers three tracks: Therapeutic Medical Physics, Diagnostic Medical Physics, Nuclear Medical Physics. Graduates of the program will be well qualified for positions in hospitals, industry, government, and academic medical centers. With a degree from a CAMPEP-accredited medical physics program, graduates are eligible for board certification in the field, a prerequisite for a clinical medical physicist position.
Accreditation status: The Medical Physics program at Stony Brook University is accredited by the Commission on Accreditation of Medical Physics Education Programs (CAMPEP).
Program name: Biomedical Engineering MSBE with emphasis in Medical Physics

Concentration name: ['Biomechanics & Mechanobiology', 'Bioimaging & Bioinstrumentation', 'Biomaterials & Regenerative Medicine', 'Bioelectricity & Biocomputing', 'Systems & Synthetic Biology']
description: The Ph.D. Program in Biomedical Engineering is designed to provide students with the advanced skills and knowledge necessary to become leaders in the field of biomedical engineering. The program is specifically structured to train students to conduct original, cutting-edge research and to prepare them for careers in academic research, government, or industry. A unique aspect of the BME graduate program is its organization into five focused research tracks based on strengths of the BME faculty: Biomechanics & Mechanobiology, Bioimaging & Bioinstrumentation, Biomaterials & Regenerative Medicine, Bioelectricity & Biocomputing, and Systems & Synthetic Biology. Students will complete didactic training and dissertation research in one of these five tracks.

The graduate program in Medical Physics provides students with a firm understanding of the principles of medical physics, and a broad knowledge of the applications of physics in medicine. The objective is to train students to be leaders in the field of Medical Physics, in academia, industry, and the clinic. The program is offered within the Department of Biomedical Engineering, and students can obtain either a Ph.D. in Biomedical Engineering with a concentration in Medical Physics, or a M.S. in Biomedical Engineering with a concentration in Medical Physics. The program includes both formal didactic coursework and opportunities for practical experience and training. Students may also participate in the extensive research programs in the departments of Biomedical Engineering, Radiology, Radiation Oncology, and Neurology.
Accreditation status: The Graduate Program in Medical Physics is accredited by CAMPEP (the Commission on the Accreditation of Medical Physics Educational Programs).
Program name: Biomedical Engineering PhD with emphasis in Medical Physics

description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Biomedical Informatics provides students with an opportunity to receive core training in the principles and methods of biomedical informatics. Students will acquire the necessary skills to collect, manage and analyze biomedical and health data for the purpose of advancing clinical care, and biomedical and translational research. The certificate is offered by the Department of Biomedical Informatics, which has primary responsibility for the curriculum. Upon completion of the program, students will be able to apply state-of-the-art computational methods to solve challenging biomedical and clinical problems. This certificate can be pursued in conjunction with another Stony Brook graduate program (e.g. MS, PhD, MD, etc.) or as a stand-alone program of study.

Concentration name: clinical informatics, translational bioinformatics, or imaging informatics
description: The Master of Science (MS) program in Biomedical Informatics (BMI) is a 33-credit, non-thesis program open to students with or without a prior computational, statistical, or biological background. Biomedical Informatics is an interdisciplinary field that combines knowledge of computer science, information science, biostatistics, and biomedical science to improve human health through research, education, and patient care. Its goal is to provide biomedical researchers and health care providers with advanced tools for the acquisition, storage, retrieval, analysis, and use of biomedical data. Students in this program will complete a set of core courses that will provide them with a strong foundation of knowledge in biomedical informatics. They will have the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas of interest through elective courses in one of three tracks: clinical informatics, translational bioinformatics, or imaging informatics. A capstone project will allow them to apply the knowledge and skills they acquired to a specific BMI research problem. Upon graduation, students in the MS-BMI program will be able to manage biomedical data, design and conduct studies that lead to new biomedical discoveries, translate these discoveries to improve the practice of medicine, and help ensure that data are used in an ethical manner. They will be competitive for BMI-related positions in academia, industry, and government.

Biomedical Informatics is the field that is concerned with the optimal use of information, often aided by the use of technology, to improve individual health, health care, public health, and biomedical research. It is a scientific discipline that is grounded in the principles of computer science, information science, cognitive science, social science, and engineering, as well as the clinical and basic biological sciences. Biomedical Informatics is a broad and exciting discipline, with many opportunities for those who wish to make an impact on any of these areas. Stony Brook University’s Department of Biomedical Informatics PhD Program has three training tracks: Clinical Informatics, which is the application of informatics and information technology to deliver healthcare services; Translational Bioinformatics, which is the development of storage, analytic, and interpretive methods to optimize the transformation of increasingly voluminous biomedical and genomic data into proactive, predictive, preventative, and participatory health; Imaging Informatics, which is concerned with the common issues that arise in all imaging, and modality-specific issues. Students receive a broad training in all areas of Biomedical Informatics, and then focus on one of these three tracks for their dissertation research.

The Master of Science (MS) in Biomedical Sciences is a one-year (30-credit) graduate program offered by the Graduate Program in the Biomedical Sciences (GBS). The curriculum provides advanced scientific training to prepare students for careers in the biomedical sciences and/or to enhance their credentials for admission to PhD, MD, DDS and other professional programs. The MS degree will be available to students in two parallel tracks with unique objectives: 1) the Medical Scholars track and 2) the Research Scholars track.

The Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics offers an M.S. program in statistics. This program is for students who are seeking a career as a practicing statistician in industry or government, or who wish to pursue a Ph.D. in statistics or a related field. The program requires 30 graduate credits. All requirements for the M.S. degree must be completed within three years of the date of matriculation. Typically, full-time students take two years to complete the M.S. degree. The statistics track is for students who want a broad education in applied statistics and who seek a general statistician’s career. It prepares students for a career as a practicing statistician in industry or government and provides a very strong background for Ph.D. studies in statistics. The statistics track has two specializations: (i) Biostatistics, and (ii) Data Science and Computational Statistics. The Biostatistics specialization is designed for students who want a career in the pharmaceutical industry or the medical field, and it also well prepares students who wish to pursue a Ph.D. in biostatistics.

The PhD program in statistics prepares students for careers as researchers and teachers in universities and as research statisticians in industry and government. The program provides rigorous training in the theory, methodology, and application of statistics. Students develop the skills to develop new statistical methods, to apply modern statistical methods to the analysis of complex data, and to collaborate effectively with domain experts. The PhD program in statistics has two tracks: (1) computational applied statistics and (2) biostatistics. The biostatistics track prepares students for careers in academia, industry (e.g., pharmaceutical and biotech), and government (e.g., FDA and NIH). The department has a long history of successful interdisciplinary collaboration with researchers in medicine, public health, biology, and many other fields. The Center for an Informed and Healthy Society (CIHS) under the Department provides a platform for such collaborations.

The Master of Professional Studies in Broadcast Meteorology at Stony Brook University’s School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences is an intensive one-year, 30-credit graduate program designed to prepare students for a career in broadcast meteorology. The program consists of a combination of core courses offered by the School of Journalism and meteorology courses within SoMAS. The program culminates in a final project creating a professional weathercast tape. Students who complete the program are eligible for the American Meteorological Society’s Certified Broadcast Meteorologist (CBM) designation. Successful graduates of the program will be qualified for a range of positions in broadcast meteorology as well as private-sector forecasting and consulting.

Concentration name: finance, marketing, health care management, innovation, or general management
description: Stony Brook's MBA program integrates an in-depth knowledge of business essentials with a focus on leadership, technology and innovation, and hands-on, project-based learning. Students learn the science of management and the art of leadership in a program that emphasizes critical thinking and creative problem-solving. Our MBA program is designed for talented professionals from a broad spectrum of academic and business backgrounds. Small class sizes, personal attention from a world-class faculty, and collaboration with a highly-motivated and diverse group of peers create an engaging learning environment where students can thrive and excel. Our flexible scheduling options (full-time, part-time, evening, and weekends) allow students to tailor their program to their needs. MBA students can focus their studies in finance, marketing, health care management, innovation, or general management. Stony Brook's MBA program is available in two convenient Long Island locations -- Stony Brook and Manhattan.
