Accreditation status: The College of Business at Stony Brook University is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

description: The Master of Science in Business Analytics (MSBA) program at Stony Brook University is a 36-credit program for full- and part-time students that focuses on advanced data analytics methods for business applications. The program aims to bridge the gap between data science and business practice by equipping students with the knowledge and skills needed to understand, manage, and act on big data. Students in this program will learn to use sophisticated data analytics tools to solve business challenges in a variety of fields such as marketing, finance, and operations. The MSBA program is a STEM-designated program. This designation allows eligible F-1 students to apply for a 24-month extension of their optional practical training (OPT).
Accreditation status: Stony Brook's College of Business is accredited by AACSB International - The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, the premier accrediting agency for business schools in the world.

description: The Stony Brook Executive Doctorate in Business Administration (DBA) is a rigorous three-year part-time doctoral program intended for high-level executives who wish to gain a deeper understanding of business theory and research to solve today's complex business problems. The Stony Brook DBA is a research-based, post-graduate degree that provides the frameworks and methodologies needed to define, analyze, and solve complex business problems. Our program provides a unique opportunity to learn how to conduct applied research with direct relevance for business practice. Students in the Stony Brook Executive DBA program will develop their business expertise and research skills through a rigorous set of core courses and close mentorship from our world-renowned faculty. With a PhD from a top-tier research institution, each faculty member is a nationally or internationally recognized scholar in their field of expertise. DBA students will have a unique opportunity to focus on a particular area of business such as finance, marketing, organizational behavior, operations management and accounting. The curriculum includes a mixture of synchronous and asynchronous coursework to offer the flexibility working executives need to balance their education with a demanding career. Synchronous coursework takes place approximately one weekend per month.
Accreditation status: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.

description:
The doctoral program in business administration at Stony Brook University's College of Business is a PhD program that develops scholars for careers in research and teaching with four areas of concentration: accounting, finance, marketing, and organizational behavior. Students are admitted into a particular area of concentration and work closely with faculty in that area.

The PhD program with a concentration in accounting prepares students for research and teaching careers in academia. The primary goal of our program is to train students to conduct rigorous and relevant accounting research that is publishable in top-tier academic journals. The program offers small classes and a collegial environment where students can work closely with faculty members. Students will receive thorough training in accounting (archival and/or analytical), econometrics, and finance.
Accreditation status: The College of Business at Stony Brook is a member of the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), the premier accrediting body for business schools worldwide. The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International.
Program name: Area of Emphasis in Accounting (Business PhD)

description: The PhD in Business Administration at Stony Brook University is a rigorous, research-intensive program that prepares students for academic careers at leading research universities. The program has areas of emphasis in finance, marketing, organizational behavior, and operations management. Our curriculum provides students with a strong foundation in the theoretical and methodological knowledge required to conduct high-quality, impactful research. The program emphasizes a mentorship model where students work closely with faculty members on research projects. Our distinguished faculty, known for their prolific scholarly contributions, will serve as your dedicated mentors, guiding you through every step of your research journey. The PhD program offers a competitive funding package that includes a stipend, tuition scholarship, and health insurance. Our graduates have successfully secured tenure-track faculty positions at well-respected universities.
Accreditation status: The College of Business at Stony Brook University is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.
Program name: Area of Emphasis in Finance (Business PhD)
Area of Emphasis in Management (Business PhD)

description: The PhD in Business Administration program is a full-time, research-oriented program that prepares graduates for academic careers at leading research universities. Our curriculum provides students with a strong foundation in their chosen discipline, as well as the statistical and methodological skills necessary to conduct high-quality, scholarly research. Students in the program select one of the following five areas of emphasis: Accounting, Finance, Marketing, Organizational Behavior, or Operations Management & Decision Analytics. Small class sizes and close interaction with faculty in classes, research projects, and the dissertation provide a supportive and challenging environment in which to develop as a scholar. Our curriculum is designed to be completed in four to five years.
Accreditation status: Stony Brook University's College of Business is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business. AACSB accreditation is the hallmark of excellence in business education and has been earned by less than five percent of the world's business programs.
Program name: Area of Emphasis in Management Science (Business PhD)

description: The Master of Science in Business Technology degree prepares students to be successful technology leaders and managers in today’s knowledge-based economy. The program has been redesigned to integrate business and technology to develop an applied understanding of the integration of people, processes, data, and devices that are so vital to every organization. The program offers students an opportunity to take advantage of cutting-edge business technology topics with practical skills to solve real-world problems. We recognize and support the growing need for leaders who can help companies navigate the world of ever-changing technology and use it as a strategic advantage.

The Graduate Program in Physiology and Biophysics at Stony Brook University is a research-intensive course of study that leads to the PhD degree. The aim of the program is to train the next generation of scientists and educators by providing a strong foundation in physiology and biophysics and to facilitate development of critical thinking and communication skills. The research interests of the faculty are diverse and encompass most modern areas of physiology, biophysics and neuroscience. Our research employs a wide range of state-of-the art techniques to address questions at the molecular, cellular, organ and whole-animal levels.
Program name: Cellular Physiology and Molecular Biophysics PhD

description: The M.S. degree in Chemical and Molecular Engineering is awarded after the successful completion of 30 graduate credits of approved courses with a cumulative grade point average of 3.0 or better. The student may select either a thesis or a non-thesis option. The thesis option requires 6 credits of thesis research in addition to 24 credits of course work. The non-thesis option requires a 3 credit design project in addition to 27 credits of course work. All students have to pass a written qualifying examination (WQ).

The graduate program in Chemical and Molecular Engineering is designed to provide students with a sound basis in chemical engineering fundamentals, as well as the advanced research skills needed to solve modern problems in chemical engineering. It is a research-oriented program leading to the Doctor of Philosophy degree. The student, in consultation with a faculty advisor, designs a program of study that best suits his or her interests and career goals. Students in the PhD program typically complete all the coursework within the first one to two years and devote the remaining time to research. There are many research opportunities available for students. Please browse our faculty profiles to find your research interest.

The Master of Arts in Teaching (M.A.T.) is a 15-month program that combines graduate-level coursework in Chemistry with pedagogical training for prospective secondary school teachers (grades 7-12). Upon successful completion of the program, students are awarded an M.A.T. degree and are recommended for New York State Initial Teacher Certification. Students completing the program may also be eligible for certification in other states, through reciprocity agreements. M.A.T. candidates take graduate courses in chemistry alongside Ph.D. students and master's students, and education courses specifically designed for M.A.T. science students, with a unique focus on how students learn science. The program includes two semesters of student teaching in local, partner districts, where candidates develop their teaching under the guidance of a highly qualified mentor teacher and a University supervisor.
Accreditation status: All of Stony Brook's teacher preparation programs are registered by the New York State Education Department and are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

description: The Department of Chemistry offers a program of graduate study leading to the Master of Science degree. The program is designed for students who desire a broader and more profound knowledge of chemistry than can be obtained in a four-year undergraduate curriculum. Since the requirements for the degree are less specialized than those for the Ph.D. degree, it offers a suitable program for students with diverse career objectives. The Master’s degree in Chemistry is available with three options: with thesis, without thesis, and with concentration in Chemical Education. In each case, a minimum of 30 graduate credits must be satisfactorily completed. An average grade of B (3.0 grade point average) or better is required. The specific course and research requirements are decided upon by the student in consultation with the Graduate Program Director. The requirements listed below are intended only as guidelines. Normally, a full-time student can complete the program within two years.

Welcome to the Graduate Program in Chemistry at Stony Brook University! The Department of Chemistry at Stony Brook is a premier center for research and education in the chemical sciences. We offer a vibrant and diverse program that includes a faculty of world-class scholars and an outstanding group of students and postdoctoral researchers. We offer a full range of degree programs in chemistry, with Ph.D. degrees in Chemical Physics and Chemistry.

The PhD program in chemistry is focused on preparing students for a variety of careers in academia, industry, and government. We provide a rigorous training program in the traditional areas of chemistry, as well as in a number of interdisciplinary areas. Our students graduate with a broad understanding of the chemical sciences, a deep knowledge in a particular research area, and the skills to succeed as independent scientists. The goal of the program is to bring each student to a level of knowledge and experimental or theoretical skill that will permit them, by the end of their program, to undertake significant research on their own. Students will take a number of graduate courses and will be required to pass a series of qualifying examinations. The major emphasis of the program is on research and the submission of an original and significant thesis is the highlight of the program. We offer students a choice of research opportunities in a wide range of areas that span the traditional disciplines of chemistry as well as interdisciplinary areas that include biological, materials, and physical sciences. Some specific research areas are listed under the faculty research pages.

This 18-credit certificate is designed for students with a BA who wish to pursue a specialization in the study of children's and young adult literature. It can be pursued as a stand-alone certificate or in conjunction with the MA. This program explores the history and development of children’s literature, its major genres, and a range of critical and theoretical approaches. Courses in children’s literature cover a variety of historical periods, from early modern to contemporary, as well as a variety of genres, from picture books and fantasy to realism and young adult literature. All courses will pay close attention to the ways in which representations of childhood are informed by issues of class, race, gender, and nation.

Concentration name: ['Structural Engineering', 'Geotechnical Engineering', 'Transportation Engineering', 'Water Resources Engineering', 'General Civil Engineering']
description: The Master of Science program is designed to provide students with the fundamentals of one or more of the civil engineering sub-disciplines. The program can be completed in three semesters of full-time study, with 30 graduate credits required for graduation. Both thesis and non-thesis options are available. The graduate program in civil engineering provides opportunities for professional development in such areas as structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, transportation engineering, and water resources and hydraulic engineering. In addition, the program offers a general option that allows the student to select a broader range of courses to meet their educational objectives.

Concentration name: ['Structural Engineering', 'Geotechnical Engineering', 'Transportation Systems Engineering', 'Water Resources and Hydraulic Engineering']
description: The Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) program in Civil Engineering is designed to prepare students for a career in research and/or academia. A high level of scholarship is expected of Ph.D. students and the program provides sufficient flexibility to allow for a focus on research in a chosen area of specialization within Civil Engineering. In consultation with their academic advisor, students design an individualized plan of graduate study and research that best meets their interests and career goals. Students must successfully complete a set of core courses and then additional coursework as advised by their Ph.D. committee to strengthen their preparation for the Qualifying examination. Students are also encouraged to participate in teaching or mentoring activities and attend departmental seminars. The Ph.D. program is centered on original research performed under the guidance of the student's research advisor culminating in a dissertation. Students entering the program with a Bachelor of Science degree should expect to spend a minimum of four years of full-time study to complete the program; those with a relevant master’s degree can complete the program in approximately three years.

The 18-credit Advanced Graduate Certificate in Coaching is a comprehensive, state-of-the-art program designed to prepare students for the New York State coaching certification. Candidates will be trained in the principles and practices of coaching as they relate to the psychological, physiological, and sociological aspects of the athlete. Candidates will complete a six-credit internship that provides an opportunity to coach under the direct supervision of a certified coach in the school setting.

The Graduate Certificate Program in Cognitive Neuroscience provides students with a solid foundation in the concepts and methods of cognitive neuroscience. Students will be exposed to a range of methodologies, including neuroimaging, electrophysiology, neuropsychology, and computational modeling. The program will involve students in the ongoing research of Stony Brook's strong and vibrant cognitive neuroscience faculty and will enrich their studies through a required proseminar that covers the most important and fundamental ideas and findings in the field.

The M.A. in Computational Linguistics is designed to prepare students for careers in the language technology industry, as computational linguists, software engineers, and data scientists. Students will gain foundational knowledge of linguistics and computer science, alongside advanced training and hands-on experience in the core areas of computational linguistics and natural language processing. The program takes place on-site at Stony Brook's main campus. It can be completed in three semesters by full-time students, or on a part-time basis. Students have the opportunity to participate in industrial internships and academic research projects as part of their studies. The curriculum includes courses on programming, algorithms, machine learning, and natural language processing, as well as courses on core areas of linguistics (phonology, syntax, and semantics). A background in linguistics, computer science, or a related field is expected.

Concentration name: Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPSA)
description:
The Master of Social Work (MSW) program prepares graduates for advanced social work practice. The School of Social Welfare offers two ways to complete your MSW degree: a full-time, two-year, 60-credit program or a part-time, three-year, 60-credit program. For applicants with a baccalaureate degree in social work (BSW) from a CSWE-accredited program, we also offer an Advanced Standing program.

In the specialized year of study, students will choose one of three specializations, which will provide them with a concentration of advanced practice skills and knowledge:

- Families, Youth and Transition to Adulthood (FYT)
- Integrated Health: Physical, Psychological and Social Well-being (IH)
- Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPSA)

Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPSA) prepares students for practice in a variety of macro settings including community organizing, legislative advocacy and policy analysis. The goal of this specialization is to create social change that will promote social and economic justice for marginalized and oppressed populations.
Accreditation status: The School of Social Welfare's MSW program is accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).
Program name: Concentration in Community and Political Social Action (MSW)

Concentration name: Cosmetics and Consumer Goods (Product Design MS)
description: This concentration focuses on the design, development, and manufacturing of consumer goods, with a particular emphasis on cosmetics and personal care products. Students will gain an understanding of the entire product lifecycle, from concept to market, including materials science, formulation, packaging, manufacturing, and regulatory compliance. The curriculum combines principles of mechanical engineering with chemistry, materials science, and business to prepare students for careers in the rapidly growing consumer goods industry. The program will provide students with the skills and knowledge to innovate and lead in the development of new products that are safe, effective, and sustainable.
Program name: Concentration in Cosmetics and Consumer Goods (Product Design MS)

description: The Educational Technology concentration focuses on understanding the design, development, use, and evaluation of instructional technology in various educational settings. It covers a broad range of topics, including learning theories and instructional design; audio and visual media design and production; web-based course development; multimedia project management; and technology integration in the classroom. This concentration prepares students to be leaders in educational organizations, instructional designers in public or corporate education, curriculum developers, instructional technologists, and technology coordinators. The four-course concentration is offered entirely online.
Program name: Concentration in Educational Technology (Technological Systems Management MS)

description: This 30 credit Master's of Science concentration in Pharmaceutical and Biopharmaceutical Product Design is a one-year program that prepares students for employment or advanced degrees in the pharmaceutical and biopharmaceutical fields. The program is designed to integrate advanced study in pharmaceutical product development, biopharmaceutical product development, and related areas. The program curriculum includes coursework in drug discovery, drug delivery, pharmacokinetics, and biopharmaceutical product development, as well as hands-on laboratory research experiences with world-renowned faculty members. Graduates will be equipped to become leaders in the field of industrial pharmaceutics and biopharmaceutics, which are rapidly expanding in the US and abroad. Students may select an M.S. with thesis or M.S. without thesis.
Program name: Concentration in Pharmaceutical and Biopharmaceutical (Product Design MS)

description: The Master of Science in Technological Systems Management (M.S.-T.S.M.) is a 30-credit degree program designed for those who have a bachelor’s degree in engineering, science, management, or the liberal arts. The degree provides an interdisciplinary education to a diverse student body of graduate students that will prepare them for careers in industry, government, or academia. In this concentration, students prepare for leadership roles in a variety of industries to ensure resilient systems. Courses focus on the application of systems engineering tools, energy and environmental systems, disaster management, water resources management, and more. This is a STEM designated program.
Program name: Concentration in Resilience and Sustainability (Technological Systems Management MS)

description: The School of Social Welfare offers a 60-credit course of study leading to the Master of Social Work (MSW) degree. The MSW program prepares students for advanced social work practice in one of two specializations: Community, Policy, and Political Social Action (CPPA) or Families, Youth, and Transition to Adulthood (FYTA). The curriculum is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in the core principles of social work, including social justice, human rights, and evidence-informed practice. Students will develop the knowledge, values, and skills necessary to work effectively with individuals, families, groups, organizations, and communities.
Accreditation status: The Master of Social Work program is fully accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).
Program name: Concentration in Social Work in Higher Education: Student-Community Development (MSW)

description: The M.S. degree in Technological Systems Management offers two options that are designed to meet the needs of both traditional students and professional managers who are working in a technological environment. The Technology Management option provides broad-based management education for those who have a technological background. The Global Technology Management option provides management education in a global context. The M.S. degree is earned by completing 30 credits of coursework as follows: Core Courses (18 credits) All students in the program must take the following six courses: EST 581 - Heuristics & Quantitative Decision-Making EST 582 - Introduction to Systems Concepts EST 562 - Strategic Marketing/Technology & Innovation EST 531 - Technology Assessment OR EST 644 - Management of Innovation EST 569 - Technology in the Workplace OR EST 580 - Advanced Technology Assessment EST 534 - Management of Engineered Systems OR EST 535 - Business and Managerial Economics. Option 1: Technology Management (12 credits) Four electives selected with the advice and consent of the graduate program director. Courses are selected from EST, business, management, public policy, or any of the engineering disciplines.
Program name: Concentration in Technology Management (Technological Systems Management MS)

description: The Executive Master of Business Administration in Health Management and Policy is designed for mid-career professionals working in a variety of healthcare settings, such as hospitals, private practices, clinics, and long-term care facilities. The program will equip them with the business skills and knowledge needed to expertly navigate our increasingly complex healthcare industry. The healthcare industry is growing faster than any other sector of the U.S. economy, with more than 2.6 million new jobs expected by 2030, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. The healthcare industry is also more competitive than ever, with more organizations competing for patients. To be successful, healthcare providers need to focus on delivering high-quality care while also managing their finances and operations effectively. The Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy will provide students with the business skills and knowledge needed to manage in healthcare. This program is designed for working professionals who aspire to or currently hold leadership positions in healthcare. The program is ideal for physicians, nurses, dentists, and other clinical and non-clinical professionals working in a variety of healthcare settings.
Accreditation status: The College of Business at Stony Brook is accredited by AACSB International-the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business, the premier accrediting agency for business schools.
Program name: Executive MBA in Health Management and Policy
Executive PhD in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Online

Concentration name: ['Student Affairs Administration', 'Higher Education Administration and Leadership']
description: The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Higher Education Administration is a post-master's program that prepares students for leadership positions in a wide variety of higher education settings, including administration, management, and student affairs. The program is specifically designed to provide a broad understanding of the increasingly complex administrative issues confronting colleges and universities. It is most appropriate for individuals who have already earned a master’s degree and who are currently employed, or who wish to be employed, in a higher education setting. The program offers two tracks: Student Affairs Administration and Higher Education Administration and Leadership. Students will select a track based on their interests and career goals.

The Master of Arts in Higher Education Administration (HEA) program is designed for current and aspiring administrators and leaders who want to advance their careers in a variety of postsecondary institutional settings, including colleges and universities, community colleges, government agencies, and associations. The program provides students with the knowledge, skills, and experiences necessary to become successful administrators and leaders in today’s colleges and universities.

The Advanced Graduate Certificate (AGC) in Human Resource Management is designed for individuals who have already earned a baccalaureate degree and wish to complete a graduate-level certificate program in human resource management. This certificate is ideal for those who are currently working in or who are planning to enter the field of human resources. The program's core curriculum gives students a solid foundation in the concepts, principles, and practices of human resource management. The curriculum is aligned with the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) HR Curriculum Guidebook and Templates. Students in the program may take the SHRM-CP exam once they have 500 hours of relevant work experience.

The Master of Science in Human Resource Management (HRM) provides students with a comprehensive understanding of human resource management strategies that create a competitive advantage for any organization. Developed with guidelines from the leading professional HR association, the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM), the curriculum covers core HRM competencies such as people, the organization, the workplace, and strategy. Courses are taught by HR professionals who have both academic qualifications and practical business experience. Students learn practical and theoretical concepts they can apply immediately to their current or future careers. The program is offered completely online, making it ideal for busy professionals and those who want the flexibility of an online learning environment.

Concentration name: Coaching, Human Resource Management, Health and Wellness Management
description: The Master of Arts in Liberal Studies (MALS) is an interdisciplinary graduate degree program that allows students to draw upon the rich and diverse graduate course offerings at Stony Brook University to create a master’s degree program that best suits their academic and professional goals. This 30-credit master’s degree allows students to fashion their graduate program in two ways. Students may choose a traditional approach to Liberal Studies and choose graduate courses from across the academic disciplines that reflect their own personal and intellectual interests. Or, students may choose a more professionally focused approach and work with the graduate program director to build a program of study using the graduate course offerings available in SPD as well as those from other graduate programs to build the graduate degree that suits their needs.

The Master of Science in Management of Technology (MS/MOT) is a 30-credit program that prepares students for leadership positions by providing the expertise to manage technological and organizational change, and to develop and implement complex business strategies in today’s demanding corporate environment. The program is designed for students with bachelor's degrees in engineering, science, or technology who are already employed or plan to seek employment in a technology-based company.

The Master of Science program in Marine Biology and Ecology is a thesis-based program designed to train students for professional positions as marine biologists or ecologists, or to prepare students for a more advanced degree in the field. The program provides students with a broad knowledge of modern marine biology and ecology, along with the research tools necessary to carry out independent study. Students complete at least 30 graduate credits of coursework, research and seminars, and a written thesis. The thesis research must be a significant piece of original work, which should be suitable for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. Coursework is determined by the student and the student’s advisory committee, depending on the student’s background and research interests.

The School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) offers a doctoral program in Marine Biology and Ecology (MBE). It is a flexible program designed for students with research interests in the biology and ecology of marine organisms. The program has particular strengths in crustacean biology, diseases of marine organisms, marine conservation, biological oceanography, and larval, physiological, population, and ecosystem ecology of a wide variety of marine organisms. Our faculty use a diversity of research approaches, including behavioral, cellular, developmental, ecological, evolutionary, genetic, molecular and physiological techniques, and apply these approaches to a variety of organisms, from phytoplankton to whales. All doctoral students are fully supported by either teaching or research assistantships and are provided tuition scholarships. Students in good standing will be supported for five years. Students may affiliate with research groups on either the main campus of Stony Brook or at the Stony Brook-Southampton campus. Prospective students should contact one or more faculty members with whom they share research interests. Admission decisions are based upon a student’s academic record (GPA, GRE scores), letters of recommendation, statement of purpose, and an interview conducted in person, by telephone or by video conferencing. Additional information can be found at the SoMAS website (www.somas.stonybrook.edu), and in the Graduate Student Handbook.

The Master of Professional Studies in Marine Conservation and Policy (MPS-MCP) is a graduate-level degree offered through the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) at Stony Brook University. The program is designed to be completed in one calendar year, and is focused on practical application of knowledge to solving problems in the marine environment. The curriculum is comprised of a set of core courses and a flexible elective curriculum that students choose from based on their interests. The MPS-MCP program culminates in a capstone project and internship that provides students with on-the-ground experience working in the marine conservation and policy field. Students will acquire the skills to: evaluate of the efficacy of current marine conservation and management initiatives; understand the underlying science that informs these initiatives; effectively communicate this science to the public and to policy-makers.

The Master of Professional Studies (MPS) in Marine Ecosystems and Society is a 12-month, 30-credit graduate degree offered through the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) at Stony Brook University. This program provides students with advanced training in the theory and practice of marine science, focusing on the interdisciplinary nature of coastal and marine issues and the need to include socioeconomic and political as well as scientific and technical considerations in environmental management. The curriculum is intended to be interdisciplinary, but can be tailored to fit the interests of each student, with potential focus on marine conservation, fisheries management, marine policy and law, or other areas within marine science. Graduates will be prepared for positions in government, not-for-profit conservation organizations and environmental consulting.

The Department of Geosciences offers a Master of Science (M.S.) degree program with concentrations in geochemistry, hydrogeology, petrology, geophysics, marine geology, surficial processes, sedimentary geology, and paleontology. Students are provided a broad background in the geosciences with an emphasis on research in one of the specialty areas. The M.S. degree requires the completion of 30 graduate credits and a research thesis. There are no specific courses that are required by the department, which allows a student, in consultation with a faculty advisor, to design a program of study that is tailored to individual needs. Each student must take at least one seminar course (GEO 599). Please consult the Graduate Bulletin for detailed course information.

The Marine Geosciences track is a 30-credit Master of Professional Studies degree that focuses on coastal processes, sediment transport, and related topics. Course topics may include coastal geology, sediment transport, marine pollution, geological oceanography, coastal zone management, and statistics. An internship and a final project are required for this track. Graduates are prepared for a variety of jobs in government and the private sector, as well as for admission to a doctoral program. Admission is for the Fall semester only and full time study is required.

The Ph.D. in Marine Geosciences is administered jointly by SoMAS and the Department of Geosciences. Please visit the Department of Geosciences Graduate Programs website for program details and admissions requirements.

The Master of Professional Science in Marine Mammal Science (MMS) is a 12-month, 30-credit, non-thesis degree program offered by the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) at Stony Brook University Southampton. The program provides students with a strong academic background in the science of marine mammalogy, while also giving them the professional skills necessary to thrive in the job market. Students will learn directly from experts that work with marine mammals in a variety of settings (e.g. government, academia, non-profit, etc.) and be exposed to the most up-to-date technologies and techniques used to study these fascinating animals. The MMS program aims to train the next generation of managers, technicians, and policy makers in the marine mammal science field. Graduates from this program will have a broad, working knowledge of the marine mammal science field and be better prepared for careers working with marine mammals in a variety of capacities (e.g. government agencies, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), non-profits, private sector, etc).

Concentration name: ['Metals and Ceramics', 'Polymers and Soft Materials', 'Computational Materials Science', 'Materials for Energy and the Environment']
description: The Master of Science degree program in Materials Science and Engineering is designed to provide students advanced training in a broad range of topics in materials science and engineering. This is primarily a course-based degree, designed to give students a strong technical background that is valued by industrial employers. The MS degree also gives students an excellent background to pursue doctoral studies. The program is flexible and may be tailored to a student’s career goals with both a thesis and non-thesis option. Our program provides specialization in four major areas of materials science and engineering: metals and ceramics, polymers and soft materials, computational materials science, and materials for energy and the environment. Graduates of the program are well prepared for professional employment in a wide range of industries including aerospace, biomedical, chemical, electronic, and semiconductor industries or for further graduate study.

The Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics offers a program of graduate study leading to the Master of Science in Quantitative Finance. This program is designed for students with strong mathematical backgrounds who wish to pursue careers in the quantitative areas of the financial industry. The program is designated as STEM. The M.S. in Quantitative Finance has a prescribed curriculum consisting of five required courses from the Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics, two required courses from the Department of Economics, and an additional three electives to be chosen from a pre-approved list of courses from the Departments of Applied Mathematics and Statistics, Computer Science, and Economics. Each student must also register for the one-credit seminar on quantitative finance for two semesters. A central feature of the program is a required summer internship with a financial institution that provides the student with hands-on experience of working in the financial industry. Upon completion of the required coursework and internship, the degree is awarded. No thesis is required. A total of 36 graduate credits is required for the M.S. in Quantitative Finance.

The Professional Option of the MA degree is intended for students who wish to pursue a career in industry. It includes courses in statistics, numerical computing, and mathematical finance, as well as an internship. The requirements for this option can typically be completed in three semesters.

Concentration name: Mathematics Track, Quantitative Finance Track, Computational and Applied Mathematics Track, Mathematics Education Track
description: The Mathematics Department offers a master's degree program in mathematics leading to the M.S. degree. The primary purpose of this program is to give students a professional education in mathematics. The M.S. program is designed for students who have a bachelor's degree in mathematics or the equivalent and who wish to obtain further training in mathematics. It is suitable as a terminal degree for those who intend to seek employment in industry or government, or at the junior college level, and it is also excellent preparation for a Ph.D. program in mathematics or a related field. There are four tracks to the M.S. degree in mathematics: the Mathematics Track, the Quantitative Finance Track, the Computational and Applied Mathematics Track, and the Mathematics Education Track. There is also an accelerated Bachelors/Masters program for Stony Brook undergraduates who wish to complete both a bachelors degree in mathematics and the M.S. degree in five years.

Concentration name: ['algebra', 'algebraic geometry', 'analysis', 'complex analysis', 'differential geometry', 'dynamical systems', 'mathematical physics', 'topology', 'quantitative finance', 'statistics']
description: The Department of Mathematics at Stony Brook is a center for research and graduate education in mathematics. The department's particular strengths are in geometry, topology, and their relation to mathematical physics. Research specializations are available in algebra, algebraic geometry, analysis, complex analysis, differential geometry, dynamical systems, mathematical physics, and topology. Students may also do research in quantitative finance or in statistics through the Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics. Members of the department have been honored with many prizes and awards, and several hold endowed chairs. The department is closely associated with the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics.

Concentration name: Design and Stress Analysis, Fluid Mechanics and Thermal Sciences, Mechanics and Materials, Operations Research, Robotics, Mechatronics and Control Systems
description: The Department of Mechanical Engineering offers a comprehensive program of graduate study and research leading to the MS and PhD degrees in Mechanical Engineering. The Master of Science (MS) program in Mechanical Engineering provides students with a high-quality and broad-based graduate education that will prepare them for careers in industry, government, or academia. Students can choose between a thesis option and a non-thesis option. The MS program with thesis is recommended for students who are interested in research-oriented careers in industry, government labs or plan to pursue a PhD degree. The MS program without thesis is recommended for students who are not planning to pursue a research career.

Concentration name: Solid Mechanics and Design, Thermal-Fluid Sciences, Mechatronics and Robotics, Materials Science, Energy and Environment, Manufacturing and Industrial Engineering
description: The graduate programs in Mechanical Engineering provide the education for students to have a successful career in industry, research or academia. We offer both M.S. and Ph.D. degrees. For both degrees, students may choose to conduct research for their thesis (M.S.) or dissertation (Ph.D.). Students who prefer to focus on coursework may choose the non-thesis M.S. degree option. The department has 33 faculty members whose expertise covers a wide range of research areas in mechanical engineering and related disciplines. Research in the department is concentrated in the following areas: Solid Mechanics and Design, Thermal-Fluid Sciences, Mechatronics and Robotics, Materials Science, Energy and Environment, Manufacturing and Industrial Engineering. The research areas described above are the areas in which a student may specialize. The Department of Mechanical Engineering is the home of several research centers and institutes, including the Advanced Energy Research and Technology Center (AERTC), the Center of Excellence in Wireless and Information Technology (CEWIT), the New York State Center for Engineering Design and Industrial Innovation (CEDI), the Mineral Physics Institute (MPI), and the Center for Mesoscale Transport Properties. Students in the graduate program conduct their research in these state-of-the-art facilities. The Department of Mechanical Engineering receives about $6M per year in external research funding from federal and state agencies as well as private companies. Currently, there are 120 full-time graduate students in the department. Most Ph.D. students are supported by either research or teaching assistantships. The stipends for Ph.D. students are highly competitive. In addition, outstanding Ph.D. applicants are considered for a number of prestigious fellowships, such as the Presidential fellowship and the STEM fellowship from the Graduate School. Ph.D. applicants with excellent academic records will automatically be considered for these fellowships.

The advanced graduate certificate in Media Management is an 18-credit program for working professionals in journalism or related fields who aspire to management positions. It’s also ideal for managers in other industries who seek a career change into media. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in media economics, marketing, leadership and ethics, and it focuses on innovation and entrepreneurship in new media and new media business models. All credits from the certificate program may be applied to the Master of Science in Journalism.

The Master of Science in Media Management at Stony Brook University prepares students to manage the business operations of today’s media organizations. The media landscape is complex. New platforms, new business models and new technologies have disrupted traditional media. Our students are prepared to navigate this exciting, ever-changing environment. They are ready to lead. The curriculum focuses on business, including courses in finance, marketing, technology, leadership and entrepreneurship. Students learn about the business of media from experts in the field. Our instructors are top executives at some of the world’s leading media companies. This is where theory and practice come together. We provide the essential business skills and the real-world perspective to build a successful career. Our flexible scheduling — with all classes offered on nights and weekends in New York City — means students don’t have to put their careers on hold to advance them.

The MM in Media Scoring and Production is a 36-credit, two-year degree program that will provide a thorough grounding in the creative, technological, historical, and practical aspects of scoring for visual media such as film, television, games, and advertising. The curriculum includes private composition lessons focused on media scoring, as well as two years of coursework in orchestration, music technology, and the history and business of media scoring. A key component of the program will be collaboration with student directors in the Stony Brook / Killer Films MFA in Film program on their film projects. Students in the MM in Media Scoring and Production will complete a culminating thesis project consisting of the score for an MFA thesis film.

The Stony Brook University MM in Media Scoring and Production is a fully online, 30-credit degree designed for aspiring and early/mid-career media composers. With a focus on scoring for film, television, video games and other interactive media, the curriculum combines traditional conservatory-style compositional training with practical, project-based coursework using the latest music technology. The program is designed to be completed in one calendar year of full-time study, with a part-time option as well, making it accessible to working professionals and students worldwide. The Stony Brook MM in Media Scoring and Production is a rigorous, professionally oriented program that will prepare you for a successful career in the fast-paced and competitive world of media scoring.
Accreditation status: The Department of Music is a fully accredited member of the National Association of Schools of Music.
Program name: Media Scoring and Production MM Online

description: The Center for Medical Humanities, Compassionate Care, and Bioethics offers an MA program to train students in the key concepts and methods of medical humanities and clinical bioethics. The program emphasizes the importance of understanding the values and cultural contexts of illness, health, and medicine, and it fosters a compassionate, patient-centered approach to healthcare. The MA program offers two tracks: Track 1 focuses on clinical ethics, designed for health care professionals, medical, and other health professions students who wish to serve as ethics consultants; Track 2 focuses on health humanities, designed for students interested in doctoral studies and academic careers in the medical/health humanities, for journalists and other professional writers who wish to specialize in writing about medicine and health, and for students in any other discipline that connects with the program’s mission.

The Certificate Program in Medical Physics at Stony Brook University is designed to provide the didactic component of the training for medical physicists in the specialty of diagnostic medical physics. The program is offered under the sponsorship of the Departments of Radiology and Radiation Oncology, and Biomedical Engineering. The program addresses the shortage of qualified medical physicists, which resulted from the changes in the requirements for certification by the American Board of Radiology (ABR). The goal is to train the next generation of medical physicists, who will ensure the safe and effective use of radiation in medicine. The program curriculum consists of a sequence of eight courses, which are offered over a two-year period, with two courses per semester. All classes are offered in the late afternoon or early evening, to accommodate students who are working full-time. Classes are offered at the Health Sciences Center, Stony Brook University.
Accreditation status: The Medical Physics Certificate Program at Stony Brook University has been granted accreditation by the Commission on Accreditation of Medical Physics Education Programs (CAMPEP).

description: The Medical Radiation Dosimetry Advanced Certificate is a full-time, 12-month program. The program is offered as either a campus-based or an online distance learning program. All students, campus-based and online, are required to complete a one-year clinical practicum at one of our many clinical affiliates. The mission of the program is to educate students to become competent, compassionate, and professional medical dosimetrists, and to provide them with the knowledge and skills necessary for a successful career in medical radiation dosimetry. The program prepares students with the fundamental concepts of radiation therapy, including radiation physics, radiobiology, anatomy and physiology, patient care, radiation safety, quality assurance, and treatment planning. The curriculum also includes instruction on the latest radiation therapy technologies, such as intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT), volumetric-modulated arc therapy (VMAT), stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), and stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT).
Accreditation status: The Medical Radiation Dosimetry Program is accredited by the Joint Review Committee on Education in Radiologic Technology (JRCERT), 20 N. Wacker Drive, Suite 2850, Chicago, IL 60606-3182, (312) 704-5300, www.jrcert.org, mail@jrcert.org. The program was awarded an 8-year accreditation in 2021.

description: The Medical Dosimetry specialization is a 12-month JRCERT-accredited advanced certificate program for experienced radiation therapists who hold a minimum of a bachelor's degree. A medical dosimetrist is a member of the radiation oncology team who has knowledge of the overall characteristics and clinical relevance of radiation oncology treatment machines and equipment, is cognizant of procedures commonly used in brachytherapy and has the education and expertise necessary to generate radiation dose distributions and dose calculations in collaboration with the medical physicist and radiation oncologist. The program is designed to provide students with the didactic and clinical skills necessary to be eligible to take the Medical Dosimetry Certification Board (MDCB) examination upon graduation. Courses are offered using a combination of in-class and online instruction. All students complete a 12-month, full-time (35 hours/week) clinical internship, which is completed at one of our affiliated medical facilities throughout the country.
Accreditation status: JRCERT-accredited

description: This program is designed for students with strong backgrounds in the physical, mathematical or engineering sciences who are interested in pursuing a career or further graduate studies in the fields of either meteorology or physical oceanography. Students are educated in the fundamentals of the dynamics of the atmosphere and ocean, and in the physical and mathematical principles underlying these disciplines. Thesis and non-thesis options are available. The thesis option involves in-depth research with a faculty member. The non-thesis option culminates with the submission of a research paper and requires a few more credits of coursework in lieu of thesis credits. All SoMAS M.S. degree programs are expected to be completed in four semesters.

The graduate program in meteorology and physical oceanography is administered by the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS). It is designed to prepare students for careers in research, teaching and applied sciences. A Ph.D. is granted to a student who has fulfilled the course requirements and has completed a dissertation that makes a significant and original contribution to the body of knowledge in their chosen field of specialization. Both theoretical and observational studies are stressed. There are two major tracks of study: meteorology and physical oceanography. The meteorology track includes studies of atmospheric dynamics, atmospheric chemistry and radiation, and cloud and precipitation physics. The physical oceanography track is concerned with the study of the physics of the ocean, including ocean circulation, ocean-atmosphere interaction, coastal oceanography and sediment transport. In both tracks, the use of numerical models and state-of-the-art instrumentation form an essential component of the graduate education experience. SoMAS has a strong program in tropical meteorology. On-campus facilities include a computing cluster and meteorological instrumentation. Students and faculty have access to research aircraft and ships, and to radar and other remote sensing facilities. Students also can participate in a wide variety of field programs on a worldwide basis. There are many opportunities to develop interdisciplinary research programs with faculty in other fields, such as chemistry and engineering. Graduate students are encouraged to gain teaching experience as well as research expertise. The goal of the program is to produce professionally competent scientists who will make fundamental contributions to the understanding of the processes that govern the dynamics of the world’s atmosphere and oceans.

The Graduate Program in Microbiology and Immunology (M&I) offers interdisciplinary training leading to the Ph.D. degree. The Program provides students with a broad knowledge base in Microbiology and Immunology and in-depth training in a selected area of research. Research opportunities in the M&I Program span the disciplines of bacteriology, immunology, virology, and molecular genetics. Students may choose to conduct research in any one of a number of areas including: mechanisms of bacterial and viral pathogenesis; host responses to infection; immune system development and function; cancer immunology; molecular genetics of bacteria, animal viruses, and host cells; and genomics. Training is supported by a large and diverse group of faculty from a number of basic science and clinical departments in the School of Medicine as well as from the adjacent Brookhaven National Laboratory. First-year students participate in three laboratory rotations, which provide an opportunity to explore a variety of research topics before selecting a thesis adviser. In addition to course work and research, students gain teaching experience by assisting in courses at the undergraduate and/or professional school level. The Program is one of ten Ph.D. programs that are part of the Graduate Program in the Biomedical Sciences at Stony Brook University. The average time to degree is five years. All students admitted to the M&I Program are supported by a stipend plus tuition waiver. First year support is provided by the Program. Thereafter, students are supported by the thesis adviser’s research grants, an institutional NIH training grant, or by individual pre-doctoral fellowships from a variety of governmental and private agencies. The M&I Program nominates outstanding applicants to the University’s Graduate Council Fellowship program; all applicants who apply by January 15 and are selected for support are considered automatically for these fellowships.

The Graduate Program in Molecular and Cellular Pharmacology is based in the Department of Pharmacological Sciences in the Renaissance School of Medicine at Stony Brook University. The program trains students for a career in biomedical research and education. The Graduate Program provides a curriculum of formal course work, research training in state-of-the-art laboratories, and teaching experiences. The central focus of the Ph.D. program is the completion of an independent research project that represents a significant, original contribution of new knowledge to the field of pharmacology. The program seeks to develop scientists who are creative, critical, and knowledgeable and can design and conduct research that is at the cutting-edge of the field of pharmacology. The research experience in the program is enhanced by a state-of-the-art research environment, which combines the facilities of the Renaissance School of Medicine, Stony Brook University, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and Brookhaven National Laboratory. Faculty research programs focus on multiple areas of molecular pharmacology, including signal transduction, systems biology, cancer biology, neuropharmacology, structural biology, and chemical biology. Graduates of the program are well prepared for the future, as the broad-based training is applicable to many areas of biomedical science. Our graduates find employment in academia, the biotechnology/pharmaceutical industry, and government.

Concentration name: Cancer Biology; Cell and Developmental Biology; Molecular Biology and Genetics; Molecular Microbiology; Neuroscience; Structural Biology and Molecular Biophysics
description: The Graduate Program in Molecular and Cellular Biology (MCB) is an interdisciplinary program of study leading to a Ph.D. degree. The Program offers broad training in the areas of molecular biology, cellular biology, genetics, microbiology, developmental biology, immunology, neurobiology, structural biology and cancer biology. More than 100 faculty from the Departments of a) Biochemistry and Cell Biology; b) Microbiology and Immunology; c) Neurobiology and Behavior; d) Pathology; e) Pharmacological Sciences; and f) Physiology and Biophysics in the College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Medicine participate in the program, thus offering students a wide choice of research experiences. The MCB Program has six major research areas: a) Cancer Biology; b) Cell and Developmental Biology; c) Molecular Biology and Genetics; d) Molecular Microbiology; e) Neuroscience; f) Structural Biology and Molecular Biophysics. Students in the MCB Program are encouraged to select a research area for their dissertation studies but are free to work with any of the participating faculty. The curriculum provides a broad foundation in molecular and cellular biology, with sufficient flexibility for students to design an advanced course of study consistent with their specific research interests.
Program name: Molecular Cell and Developmental Biology PhD

description: The MFA in Motion Pictures is an intensive three-year, 60-credit terminal degree program in which students are trained in all aspects of filmmaking, from writing to directing to post-production. Our philosophy is that a successful filmmaker in the 21st century has to understand the process from beginning to end. With a story-driven focus, students write, direct and edit their own films. In addition, they serve in a variety of production roles on their cohort’s films, including cinematographer and producer, and get a strong technical grounding in sound, lighting, editing and the business of film. Students will complete multiple films, culminating in their thesis film, which will be supported by a written thesis document articulating their creative process and artistic ambitions. The program offers a diverse and experienced faculty, as well as renowned guest artists, to help students develop their professional skills and cultivate their artistic vision. Killer Films, a leading independent film company, is Stony Brook’s partner, providing students a unique opportunity to interact with an active film production company. The program culminates in a showcase in New York City, attended by industry professionals. Graduates will leave with the professional skills to launch a career in the film industry and the artistic skills to create their own motion pictures.

The M.A. program in philosophy is a two-year program designed for students who want to develop their knowledge in philosophy in a systematic way and improve their abilities in critical thinking, writing, and reading. The M.A. program offers two tracks: the Academic Track, designed for students planning to go on for a Ph.D. in philosophy or a related field; and the Professional Ethics Track, for students planning careers in fields outside of academia such as business, law, journalism, or medicine, who want a solid grounding in ethics and value theory. Students in the Academic Track write an M.A. thesis, while those in the Professional Ethics Track take a comprehensive exam. Both tracks provide excellent training for a variety of careers.

The graduate program in philosophy has a strong pluralistic orientation and is especially known for its focus in the area of nineteenth and twentieth-century continental philosophy. Areas of specialization include Continental Philosophy since Kant (Phenomenology, Existentialism, Hermeneutics, Structuralism, Post-Structuralism, Deconstruction, Critical Theory, Psychoanalysis, Feminism), Ethics (and its history, ancient, modern, and contemporary), Social and Political Philosophy (and its history), Philosophy of Art (Aesthetics), Philosophy of Race, and Philosophy and Psychoanalysis. The program offers a broad range of courses, and works closely with many other departments and programs, such as Art, Comparative Literature, Cultural Analysis and Theory, English, European Languages, Hispanic Languages, History, Political Science, Sociology, and Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. The department hosts a number of lecture series and conferences each year, and is the home of the journal, "Continental Philosophy Review" as well as "Epoché: A Journal for the History of Philosophy". The department has a very active graduate student organization, which hosts its own annual conference and "brown bag" series of talks.

The Ph.D. in Health and Rehabilitation Sciences with a concentration in Physical Therapy is a post-professional research-oriented program designed to prepare physical therapists for a career in academia or research. The program provides an opportunity for students to work with faculty with established research agendas in focused areas of study. Areas of focus include motor control, biomechanics and motor learning with research emphasis in such populations as stroke, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s disease, cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury and geriatrics. Students may have the opportunity to participate in teaching in the professional DPT curriculum based upon their experience and interest.

The Department of Physics and Astronomy offers graduate programs leading to the Master of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy degrees in physics and the Doctor of Philosophy degree in astronomy and astrophysics.

Welcome to the Graduate Program in Physics & Astronomy at Stony Brook University. We are a large and intellectually vibrant department with a distinguished history of research and education. Our graduate program is one of the top programs in the country, and we welcome talented students from all over the world to join our community. Stony Brook Physics and Astronomy is particularly strong in nuclear physics, condensed matter physics, and astrophysics, but we have strong programs in AMO, and high energy physics as well. The Department of Physics and Astronomy offers a full-time program of study leading to the Ph.D. degree in Physics. Students in the program may also obtain a M.A. degree in passing. Our Ph.D. students are active partners in the research of the department. They work closely with faculty members and are crucial to the success of our research programs. Most of our students go on to very successful careers at academic institutions, national laboratories or in industry.

description: The Program in Biomedical Sciences (PIBS) is an interdepartmental and inter-institutional umbrella admissions program for doctoral study at Stony Brook University. PIBS serves as a gateway to ten of our PhD programs, providing first-year students with a broad-based, interdisciplinary training experience. Students in PIBS complete three laboratory rotations and take a combination of core and elective courses before choosing a dissertation lab and a specific PhD graduate program at the end of their first year. All students accepted into PIBS are awarded a nationally-competitive stipend, a full-tuition scholarship and subsidized health insurance.

The 100% online MA in Popular Music Pedagogy is the first degree program of its kind in the United States. Its curriculum is designed for music teachers who wish to develop skills in popular music performance, composition/songwriting, and pedagogy for use in the classroom. Current K-12 teachers who do not have the time to attend classes in person will now be able to obtain a master's degree from a nationally recognized music department, while learning from a core faculty of experienced teachers and active popular musicians. Students can also specialize in one of three concentrations: Performance, Composition, or Music Technology. The program may be completed in one calendar year of full-time study.
Accreditation status: The Department of Music at Stony Brook University is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Music.

description: The MS in Prevention Science and Community Health prepares graduates to serve as practitioners who promote well-being and identify and address public health problems in communities, including health departments, non-profits, healthcare systems, and research settings. Graduates of the program are also well-prepared to enter doctoral programs in public health and related fields. The program has a strong focus on community-engaged prevention research and practice, and provides students with the fundamental skills for developing, implementing, and evaluating programs that address the behavioral and social determinants of health in communities. Students develop strong research skills and learn to use a range of quantitative and qualitative methods to understand how to promote health and health equity. Upon graduation, all students will have had an opportunity to work collaboratively on a community-based, faculty-mentored master's project and will have completed an applied practice experience with a community partner agency. This program is offered full-time (three semesters) and part-time. The curriculum follows a hybrid model with a combination of in-person and online courses.
Accreditation status: The Program in Public Health is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH).
Program name: Prevention Science and Community Health MS

description: The Prevention Science and Community Health PhD Program prepares students to become leading researchers who can develop, implement, and evaluate effective and culturally-tailored health promotion and disease prevention programs. The program provides doctoral-level training in the theoretical and methodological basis of prevention science and community health. Students will develop competence in a wide range of relevant theoretical frameworks and research methods, including qualitative and quantitative data collection, survey research, research design (including experimental and quasi-experimental designs), and advanced statistical analysis. Our faculty have expertise in a broad range of areas, including health disparities, cancer prevention and control, chronic disease prevention, global health, HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted infections, implementation science, community-based participatory research, health communication, and environmental health. The program draws on an interdisciplinary framework grounded in the public health perspective of understanding the interplay of individual, social, and environmental determinants of health.
Accreditation status: The Program in Public Health at Stony Brook University is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH).
Program name: Prevention Science and Community Health PhD

description: This Focus area is for those interested in creating new products or improving existing ones that are user-friendly, functionally appropriate, aesthetically pleasing, and meet a wide variety of requirements. Students take courses in creative design, conceptual design, engineering design, product manufacturing, and prototyping to prepare them for industrial positions in product design and development.

The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Program Evaluation provides a strong foundation in the concepts and methods of program evaluation across the disciplines of education, public health, social work, public policy and administration, and criminal justice. This 18-credit, fully online certificate program offers students both a theoretical and a practical framework for carrying out program evaluation. The Advanced Graduate Certificate in Program Evaluation prepares students for careers as evaluation specialists in a range of nonprofit, governmental, educational, and for-profit settings. Students will be well positioned to pursue careers as program evaluators, directors of research and evaluation, and monitoring and evaluation specialists. The Certificate will provide those currently in professions which utilize program evaluation with the formal knowledge and skill sets to serve as leaders in the field.

The advanced certificate program for the Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner (PMHNP) is designed to provide the master’s-prepared nurse practitioner with the theoretical knowledge and clinical experience to become a competent, safe and effective psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner who can provide care for individuals, families, and groups with a variety of psychiatric and mental health needs. The program consists of 28 credits of the required specialty courses and 500 hours of clinical preceptorships. On completion of the certificate program, graduates will be eligible to take the psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner certification examination offered by the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC). The program can be completed in four semesters on a part-time basis.
Accreditation status: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, Doctor of Nursing Practice program and post-graduate APRN certificate programs at Stony Brook University School of Nursing are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education (CCNE), 655 K Street, NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.
Program name: Psychiatric Mental Health Nurse Practitioner Certificate
